If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more discussion and resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: HARBINGER
sets.description:
• With its high power and great STAB combination, Hydreigon makes for a formidable attacker.

  • Tera Blast can be used in tandem with an Electric Tera type to deal heavy damage to Dondozo.

  • Flamethrower is useful for hitting Steel-types such as Scizor and otherwise decent Dark Pulse switch-ins like Meowscarada.

  • Flash Cannon is Hydreigon’s best option to hit Fairy-types such as Mimikyu.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf patches up Hydreigon’s somewhat lackluster Speed, allowing it to threaten a wider portion of the metagame with its high-powered attacks.

  • Choice Specs: If your team has another Scarf user, Choice Specs Hydreigon is a nuclear wallbreaker that can pummel unsuspecting teams.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type can be used to get around the many Dragon and Fairy-types that try to revenge kill Hydreigon, though it is still vulnerable to Mach Punch from Breloom.

  • Electric: Thanks to Levitate and a Tera type of Electric, Hydreigon lacks any sort of weaknesses, and gains a powerful Tera Blast to hit Dondozo with, being able to break past it without fearing Fissure.

  • Dark: Tera-boosted Dark Pulse is an absurdly powerful weapon, and when coupled with its flinch rate, Tera Dark Hydreigon can potentially muscle its way out of otherwise hopeless situations.

  • Fire: Terastallizing into the fire typing will grant Hydreigon a resistance to Fairy-types while removing its weakness to Fighting-types and giving it a good move to hit Steel-types with. However, unlike Tera Steel it does not grant a resistance to Dragon, and it also gives Hydreigon a few new weaknesses.

sets.name: Versatile Attacker
sets.description:
• Hydreigon's useful support movepool can add quite a bit of unpredictability to its offensive potential.

  • Note that this Hydreigon is fully capable of running three attacking moves with one support move.

  • Substitute is excellent for scouting Terastallization and punishes common status users such as Yawn Dondozo.

  • When Terastallizing Hydreigon, Thunder Wave is often the safest move against other faster Dragon-types that Terastallize, such as Dragapult and Salamence.

  • Taunt is good for getting the edge against defensive foes such as Clodsire.

  • Nasty Plot makes Hydreigon a surprisingly dangerous sweeper against slower teams.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type has fantastic synergy with Levitate, helping Hydreigon against Dragon- and Fairy-types without the dreaded Ground weakness.

  • Dark: Since so few Pokemon resist Dark-type attacks, this is a good Tera type for cleaning up late game.

  • Poison: With a Poison Tera type, Hydreigon can do well against Fairy-types without fear of powerful Fighting-type attacks.

  • Fire: When using Flamethrower, a Fire Tera type is handy for both the Fairy resistance and a better matchup against Kingambit.

Items

  • Leftovers: If using Substitute, Leftovers's extra bit of recovery helps reduce its risk.

  • Life Orb: A simple power boost still comes in handy, even if only using two attacks.

  • Black Glasses: If a teammate is already using Life Orb, Black Glasses is a good compromise.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Hydreigon's new access to Stealth Rock makes it a surprisingly effective offensive support Pokemon.

  • Taunt effectively shuts down common support leads like Hippowdon and Clodsire.

  • Thunder Wave is a powerful deterrent against offensive foes and can even stop sweepers in emergency situations when used with Focus Sash.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Thanks to Levitate, a Steel Tera type is an incredible defensive typing for Hydreigon, giving it an advantage over Fairy- and Dragon-types.

  • Poison: Tera Poison is a good alternative to Steel, with fewer resistances but an important Fighting-type resistance.

  • Dark: If using Life Orb, boosting Dark-type attacks can make for some surprising late-game cleaning.

  • Fire: Fire-type Hydreigon is better against Kingambit and Fairy-types.

Items

  • Leftovers: If using Taunt, Leftovers is the best choice for giving Hydreigon longevity against defensive foes such as Corviknight.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash makes setting up Stealth Rock a much easier task against offensive teams. Be warned that it doesn't stop Dragapult's Dragon Darts.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb lets Hydreigon be played more offensively if setting Stealth Rock isn't needed.

  • Dark Glasses: Dark Glasses work if a teammate is using Life Orb.

vgc2023.overview:
• Hydreigon is a strong contender for the title of best Pokemon in the Series 1 metagame thanks to its diverse movepool and high damage output.

  • Terastallization proves to be a boon for Hydreigon, as it can get rid of its ever-burdening Fairy-type weakness by changing to much more beneficial types such as Steel.

  • Hydreigon has a good offensive typing, leaving few Pokemon able to switch in safely. It is one of the best checks to Gholdengo and also pairs well with it, forming a fundamentally powerful core when used with Tailwind support from Murkrow. Armarouge and Garchomp also synergize well with Hydreigon, covering for Steel-types, which it may not be able to damage effectively depending on its Tera type. Hydreigon can, however, struggle against damage reduction such as Snarl and Light Screen, with the latter coming especially from Grimmsnarl, which can easily take its STAB moves and OHKO it back with Spirit Break if Hydreigon is not Terastallized. Repeated usage of Draco Meteor can also make Hydreigon deal unimpressive amounts of damage, but this can be counteracted with Haze from Murkrow, allowing it to continue dealing devastating damage.

sets.name: Life Orb
sets.description:
• Tailwind allows Hydreigon to support allies such as Armarouge and Sylveon, forming strong offensive combinations. The third moveslot depends on Hydreigon's Tera Type and can be changed accordingly. Protect is utilized on teams with a different primary Tailwind setter such as Murkrow, but Hydreigon can still be kept as a secondary setter.

  • Life Orb lets Hydreigon dish out consistent damage without the need to set up.

  • The Steel Tera type synergizes wonderfully with Hydreigon's original typing and Levitate, allowing it to resist a plethora of common types such as Fairy, Ground, and, Dragon. This makes Hydreigon one of the best checks to Tera Ground Garchomp, which cannot hit Hydreigon with Earthquake and deals minimal damage to it with Dragon Claw and Rock Slide. A Fire Tera type allows Hydreigon to beat opposing Tera Steel Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Salamence. The Poison Tera type lets Hydreigon maintain the resistance to Fairy that Steel and Fire possess while also gaining an additional resistance to Fighting, crucial against the likes of Annihilape, Hariyama, and Close Combat Lycanroc. It is only left with Psychic as a relevant weakness, synergizing well with its original Dark typing. Tera Blast should be used instead of Flash Cannon for coverage against Fairy-types on sets that use Tera Poison.

sets.name: Scope Lens
sets.description:
• Heat Wave is a great coverage move to deal with Steel-types that can withstand Draco Meteor such as Gholdengo and Kingambit.

  • Scope Lens takes advantage of the +2 critical hit rate from Focus Energy, allowing Hydreigon to always critical hit, especially through Draco Meteor Special Attack drops and other means of damage reduction such as Light Screen.

  • A Timid nature lets Hydreigon speed tie other Hydreigon as the raw power it gains from having the ability to always critical hit is enough. A Modest nature can, however, be utilized on teams with good methods of speed control such as Tailwind from Murkrow.

  • The Fire Tera type powers up Hydreigon's Heat Wave, letting it OHKO Kingambit on a critical hit and nearly OHKO Amoonguss, and gives Hydreigon a Fairy resistance.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Snarl is an immensely useful tool for reducing the damage dealt by strong special attackers such as Gholdengo, Psychic Terrain-boosted Expanding Force Armarouge, and opposing Hydreigon.

  • Flash Cannon in combination with the Steel Tera type is used as a way to keep Fairy-types such as Grimmsnarl and Sylveon in check. Heat Wave is used as coverage to hit opposing Steel-types, but Dark Pulse is usually preferred over it for its ability to deal consistent damage to most other types overall.

  • Assault Vest makes Hydreigon a very potent sponge against special moves when combined with its ability to use Snarl for further reduction, especially for its teammates. Its high Special Attack lets it deal respectable damage despite running a more support-oriented set.

  • The Speed EVs allow Hydreigon to outrun maximum Speed Timid Gholdengo, and as a result, Armarouge of all Speed investments, allowing it to immediately use Snarl and lower their damage output. The Special Attack EVs let it always 2HKO maximum HP and 4 Special Defense Armarouge and uninvested Gholdengo with Dark Pulse. The Special Defense EVs make -1 Modest maximum Special Attack Choice Specs Gholdengo's Shadow Ball only a possible 5HKO on Tera Steel Hydreigon, while Make It Rain rocks a petty chance to even 7HKO. -1 Armarouge Aura Sphere also only has about a 50% chance to 4HKO Hydreigon. Note that Hydreigon should not be Terastallized against Armarouge to maintain the Fire resistance and Psychic immunity, as it is still weak to Aura Sphere when Terastallized. Opposing Tera Fire Hydreigon never OHKOes Tera Steel Hydreigon with Life Orb Heat Wave when spread damage is accounted for, allowing Hydreigon to retaliate with Snarl. The physical bulk allows Hydreigon to never be 2HKOed by maximum Attack Adamant Annihilape Drain Punch and Jolly maximum Attack Garchomp Brick Break.

  • Steel Tera type is the best defensive type for Hydreigon, allowing it to hard check most special attackers such as Gholdengo and Sylveon while holding its own against Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl. Poison Tera type, on the other hand, lets Hydreigon maintain the Fairy resistance that Steel gives it while also awarding it an additional resistance to Fighting in the face of Pokemon such as Annihilape and Hariyama. Tera Blast should be used instead of Flash Cannon to hit Fairy-types on Tera Poison sets.

Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Quiver Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
• With Flame Body, several physical attackers like Annihilape, Meowscarada, and Mimikyu can be crippled on contact, which helps a lot.

  • Quiver Dance lets Volcarona sweep, alongside the possibility of Fiery Dance further boosting Special Attack. Fire Blast can be used if greater damage output is wanted.

  • Giga Drain is the best coverage option for Volcarona, as it helps it deal with Water-type Pokémon, as well as recover a good amount of HP.

  • Water-type Tera Blast helps Volcarona deal with Pokemon like Skeledirge, Ceruledge, and other Volcarona. Volcarona with Bug Buzz can also be used, as it is a very powerful STAB move and helps Volcarona deal with Hydreigon.

Tera Types

  • Water: Terastallizing into the Water typing nullifies Volcarona's most common weakness in Rock-type. Tera Blast damages Hydreigon decently prior to Terastallizing. Water-type Tera Blast is also the best option Volcarona has to hit Skeledirge.

  • Grass: The Grass typing strengthens Giga Drain and nullifies Volcarona's weakness to Water-types, most notably helping against Dondozo and Rotom-W.

  • Fire: Terastallizing into Fire typing makes Volcarona's Fire Blast even more powerful.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: It is the best option on Volcarona, as it circumvents its crippling Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry helps Volcarona accrue boosts more easily with Quiver Dance and lets it avoid being 2HKOed by Mimikyu and Dragonite.

  • Life Orb: This is the most reliable tool for helping Volcarona sweep in the late-game.

sets.name: Bulkarona
sets.description:
• With recovery and massive investments in bulk, Volcarona is capable of setting up multiple Quiver Dances, giving it new opportunities to sweep.

  • Even before Terastallization, Tera Blast can come in handy for hitting Hydreigon.

  • Giga Drain is Volcarona's best shot at beating Water-types such as Rotom-W and Palafin; note that Dondozo is not 2HKOed.

  • Will-O-Wisp is great for punishing boosting physical attackers that may Terastallize, such as Kingambit.

  • Bug Buzz is Volcarona's best tool against foes behind a Substitute, and hits Hydreigon hard.

  • Though it can be difficult to fit-in, Substitute allows Volcarona to punish users of status moves, such as sleep moves from Amoonguss, Breloom, and Sylveon, and Toxic from Water Absorb Clodsire.

  • The given EV spread maximizes Volcarona's overall bulk, while outspeeding Meowscarada after Quiver Dance.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type lets Volcarona punish foes like Choice Band Dragapult, at the cost of being far more vulnerable to Tera Steel Dragons and Kingambit.

  • Water: Besides removing all of Volcarona's old weaknesses, a Water Tera type also 2HKOes Skeledirge with Tera Blast.

  • Grass: With a Grass Tera type, Volcarona can now 2HKO most Dondozo with Giga Drain and is better insulated against Rotom-W revenge kills.

  • Flying: While a Flying Tera Type isn't a huge help defensively, the immunity to Fissure makes Volcarona better equipped to handle Dondozo.

  • Fire: A Fire Tera type simply gives Fiery Dance more power, and makes sense if not using Tera Blast.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Stealth Rock is common enough that this is the safest item for Volcarona to hold.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry gives Volcarona more durability against teams that lack hazards.

  • Safety Goggles: This allows Volcarona to handle Spore from Breloom and Amoonguss without Terastallizing.

sets.name: SOLAR FLARE (Choiced Attacker)
sets.description:
• With its high Speed and immediate power, Volcarona is a good candidate for a choice item.

  • With its high chance to boost Volcarona’s Special Attack, Fiery Dance is a potent cleaning tool.

  • Bug Buzz is a good secondary STAB move that allows Volcarona to hit foes hiding behind a substitute.

  • Overheat deals good immediate damage, which can allow Volcarona to muscle past otherwise annoying walls.

  • Giga Drain is Volcarona’s best option to hit Dondozo.

  • Tera Blast can be used with various Tera types to augment Volcarona’s coverage, helping it get around its somewhat limited movepool.

  • Since Stealth Rock is relatively less common in Battle Stadium Singles, Volcarona can serve as a rather reliable pivot with U-turn.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf Volcarona outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame, allowing it to revenge kill and pivot very effectively.

  • Choice Specs: With the extra power offered by Choice Specs, Volcarona becomes even more difficult to wall, even potentially breaking through some resists with its attacks.

Tera Types

  • Fire: A Fire Tera type slightly improves Volcarona’s defensive profile while boosting Fiery Dance and Overheat even further, allowing it to grab some surprising KOs.

  • Fairy: When paired with Tera Blast, a Fairy Tera type allows Volcarona to better handle the many Dragon-types in the metagame; notably, it is Volcarona's best option for beating Dragonite.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type allows Volcarona to resist the many Water-type attacks aimed at it and gives it a better chance at breaking past Dondozo.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Volcarona's great defensive typing and solid bulk makes it a good defensive pivot for threats such as non-Stakeout Iron Valiant and Slither Wing while checking Iron Bundle and Quaquaval with Desolate Land. Morning Sun gives Volcarona a boosted recovery under Desolate Land, and Will-O-Wisp enables Volcarona to cripple its switch-ins. The 32 Speed EVs allow Volcarona to outpace and burn uninvested Garchomp with Will-O-Wisp. Specially defensive walls like Ice Scales Corviknight appreciate Volcarona's ability to switch into to mixed threats like Iron Valiant. Specially offensive Ghosts like Dragapult and Gholdengo also appreciate Volcarona's ability to spread burns and allow them to utilize Hex at full power. Heavy-Duty Boots is vital for Volcarona's longevity, so it is recommended to pair Volcarona with a Knock Off switchin like Great Tusk or Iron Hands to mitigate the chance of being vulnerable to entry hazards.

sets.name: Fast Utility
sets.description:
Tera Ghost allows Talonflame to check Maushold and Swords Dance Lucario, spinblock, and remove its weakness to Stealth Rock if it loses its item. It also gives Talonflame an emergency immunity to Boomburst from Noivern and Toxtricity and lets Taunt sets beat Quagsire and Gastrodon.

Tera Steel instead lets Talonflame gain a resistance to Stealth Rock and Extreme Speed, as well as an immunity to Toxic and poison, which helps against Grafaiai. It can also let it serve as a serviceable Staraptor switch-in, although it must beware of Close Combat. It must also be careful to not Terastallize if it still needs to handle Slither Wing.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Florges leverages its great defensive typing, high PP recovery move in Wish, and Fur Coat to blanket check physical threats such as Great Tusk, Dragonite, and Iron Valiant. Synthesis gives Florges more recovery PP at the cost of making Wish less safe to use. Calm Mind can turn Florges into a late-game wincon. Leftovers bolsters Florges's recovery, while Heavy-Duty Boots reduces the damage it takes from frequent switches in. Trick + Choice Scarf Florges can cripple foes like Corviknight and set up on them with Calm Mind; however, it forgoes Wish's recovery PP for this. Defensive partners like Ice Scales Corviknight and Toxapex can help Florges by switching into Steel- and Poison-types that threaten it, like Gholdengo and Iron Moth; in return, they appreciate Florges switching into physical attackers like Iron Hands and Roaring Moon for them. Offensive partners like Kingambit and Dragapult appreciate Florges's Wish giving them more chances to wallbreak.

sets.name: CUTESY CRUSADER (Defensive)
sets.description:
• With its good bulk and Special Attack, Sylveon is quite a dangerous threat and is also hard to take down.

  • With the boost from Pixilate, Hyper Voice becomes Sylveon’s best option for STAB, notably bypassing Substitute.

  • A Fire-type Tera Blast provides excellent coverage against the many Steel-types that try to take advantage of Sylveon.

  • Wish can be used to keep Sylveon healthy, as well as its teammates.

  • Shadow Ball offers important coverage on Gholdengo without demanding that Sylveon Terastallize.

  • Quick Attack, though weak, can be very helpful for finishing off foes that have hung on against Sylveon or its teammates, and thanks to Pixilate, Ghost-types cannot safely switch in to absorb the move.

Tera Types

  • Fire: Beyond improving Tera Blast, a Fire Tera type grants Sylveon resistances to Steel and Fairy, allowing it to take on foes it would otherwise have to run from, such as Gholdengo.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• With its good natural bulk, Sylveon can serve as a potent attacker and decent revenge killer.

  • Thanks to Pixilate, Hyper Voice is Sylveon’s best STAB option, notably bypassing Substitute.

  • Tera Blast serves as a good alternate STAB attack once Sylveon has Terastallized, providing highly valuable coverage against the Steel-types that could otherwise exploit it, like Scizor.

  • Shadow Ball hits foes such as Mimikyu and Gholdengo super effectively, and it means Sylveon does not have to Terastallize to hit Gholdengo for good damage.

  • Though it is weak, Quick Attack gives valuable priority for picking off weakened threats, and thanks to Pixilate, surprise users of Tera Ghost aren't able to absorb it.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest lets even offensive Sylveon be specially resilient, but it doesn't allow Wish or Yawn to be used.

  • Choice Specs: With the boost from Choice Specs, Sylveon is a surprisingly potent wallbreaker, making the most out of its many opportunities to switch in.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA: This spread capitalizes on Sylveon's good natural bulk while maximizing its power.

  • 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: While no bulk investment makes Sylveon more difficult to safely get in, Speed investment allows it to outrun and threaten a wider range of foes, such as Scizor and Corviknight.

vgc2023.overview:
• Sylveon is a great Pokemon in Series 1 thanks to a strong Pixilate-boosted Hyper Voice, potentially further boosted by Throat Spray and Calm Mind.Its Fairy typing is especially strong in a metagame with plenty of good Dark-, Dragon-, and Fighting-types like Grimmsnarl, Hydreigon, Hariyama, and Annihilape.

  • Sylveon's Speed means that it can effectively take advantage of both Trick Room and Tailwind from Pokemon like Amrarouge and Murkrow; 212 Speed EVs, taken from Sylveon's HP, can be run on Tailwind teams to outpace Dragapult.

  • Sylveon can struggle against Fire-types like Ceruledge and Armarouge, which makes Pokemon like Rotom-W, Paldean Tauros-A, and Dragonite good teammates. Sylveon also appreciates Pokemon like Ceruledge and Garchomp that can handle Gholdengo.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Tera Blast + Fire Tera type gives Sylveon a strong matchup against Steel-types like Gholdengo and Tera Steel Hydreigon. When not Terastallized, Tera Blast is boosted by Pixiliate and is still useful for dealing damage when faced by Wide Guard users like Armarouge. Fairy Tera type makes Sylveon's Hyper Voice even more powerful, letting it 2HKO even naturally bulky Pokemon like Kingambit and Hatterene; this can be used over Fire Tera type on teams that can afford the loss in effectiveness against Steel-types like Gholdengo. Ground Tera type is an option that lets Sylveon hit opposing Fire-types like Ceruledge and Armarouge hard, retain good damage against Steel-types, and avoid a burdensome weakness to Garchomp, though Sylveon strongly values the resistance to Steel that a Fire Tera type grants.

  • Substitute is good for blocking Amoonguss's Spore, preventing its Clear Smog from resetting Sylveon's stat boosts, and taking advantage of defensive play. Quick Attack is an option that can prove particularly useful against Tailwind teams, picking off Pokemon brought down to their Focus Sash like Murkrow and Kilowattrel, as well as other weakened Pokemon.

  • Calm Mind is an option that can be particularly potent on bulkier teams with damage mitigation from Pokemon like Gyarados and Grimmsnarl to help Sylveon set up.

  • Throat Spray is a no-drawback way of improving Sylveon's offense; a +1 Hyper Voice will 2HKO most offensive Pokemon that do not resist Fairy. Life Orb lets Sylveon immediately 2HKO or nearly 2HKO most offensive Pokemon at the cost of recoil that could put it in range of attacks like Tera Ground Garchomp's Earthquake. Leftovers is good alongside Calm Mind on bulkier teams where Sylveon wants to stick around longer. Safety Goggles grants Sylveon immunity to Amoonguss's Spore.

  • On Tailwind teams Sylveon can run 212 Speed EVs, taken from its HP stat, to outpace Dragapult.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs is Sylveon's most immediately powerful set, it can 2HKO most offensive Pokemon that do not resist Fairy. It's much more immediately powerful than Throat Spray Sylveon and a bit stronger than Life Orb Sylveon without wearing itself down with recoil, helping it stay out of range of attacks like Tera Ground Garchomp's Earthquake.

  • Tera Blast + a Fire Tera Type lets Sylveon hit Fairy-resistant foes like Gholdengo and Amoonguss hard, and the typing is defensively useful against the former. Tera Blast is also useful by itself in the face of Wide Guard, giving Sylveon an option besides Hyper Beam, which has a turn of recharge, for a single target Fairy-type attack.

  • Shadow Ball hits Armarouge, Ceruledge, and Skeledirge, which resist Fairy, and is a strong option against Gholdengo and Gengar if Terastallizing is off the table.

  • Hyper Beam OHKOes bulky Pokemon like Rotom-W and Kingambit that can take Hyper Voice.

  • 212 Speed EVs, taken from Sylveon's HP stat, let it outpace Dragapult on Tailwind teams.

sets.name: Dual Screens (Steel)
sets.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Fur Coat Avalugg blanket checks physical attackers in the tier with its gargantuan bulk. Rapid Spin makes it a passable entry hazard remover, removing hazards against foes like Garchomp and Hippodown, backed by a powerful Body Press to hit switch-ins like Corviknight. Crunch can also be used to hit foes like Skeledirge and Gholdengo well, preventing them from spinblocking. Avalugg fits on more defensive teams that can cover its weaknesses more easily, so it should be paired with Ice Scales users like Blissey and Garganacl that can switch into special attackers like Iron Bundle and Dragapult. Fire- and Fighting-type switch-ins like Toxapex and Skeledirge can switch into physical attackers Avalugg cannot check, like Ceruledge and Slither Wing; in return, Avalugg switches into Pokemon like Baxcailbur and Chien-Pao for them. Avalugg has trouble removing entry hazards versus most Ghost-types, so other hazard removers like Corviknight and Great Tusk can help it out greatly.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Frisk lets Noivern scout for items such as Choice Scarf from Sandy Shocks. Infiltrator can be used to hit Gengar with Draco Meteor through Substitute and be more threatening versus dual screens teams. Tera Normal gives Noivern a huge power boost on Boomburst, letting it guarantee an OHKO versus Quagsire.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description: 52 Speed EVs allows Oricorio-Pom-Pom to outspeed Talonflame after a Quiver Dance, with the remaining EVs being invested in HP and Defense to take hits more easily from priority users like Lokix, Slither Wing, and Lucario. Tera Ground transforms Revelation Dance into a Ground-type attack, hitting foes like Tinkaton, Tyranitar, and Sandy Shocks for super effective damage.

sets.name: Ice Scales
sets.description: Ice Scales Toxapex utilizes its remarkable special bulk and valuable defensive typing to check offensive threats such as Chi-Yu, Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and non-Mold Breaker Iron Bundle. The combination of Toxic + Haze lets Toxapex shut down and eventually beat setup sweepers that try to overwhelm it such as Dragonite, Ceruledge, and Volcarona. Liquidation pressures Toxic-immune foes like Clodsire and Kingambit. Toxic Spikes is an option to spread status more easily, which works well with Hex users such as Gholdengo and Dragapult. Fur Coat users like Corviknight and Hippowdon can check threatening foes like Great Tusk and Iron Hands for it; Corviknight's Defog also relieves entry hazard pressure from Toxapex if not running Heavy-Duty Boots, while Hippowdon's Stealth Rock works well with Toxapex's poison to spread further passive damage.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Salazzle should rarely be Terastillized, as it loses its 4x resistance to First Impression from Slither Wing and Lokix and doesn't notably benefit from any type change.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: The given Speed EVs allow Tsareena to outspeed Kilowattrel after a Rapid Spin. Although Tsareena should Terastallize rarely, Tera Steel helps Tsareena act as an emergency check to Staraptor and Gengar by tanking Brave Bird and Sludge Bomb respectively and allowing it to decently chip them.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature allow Tsareena to outspeed Iron Bundle under Tailwind, retain enough Attack to OHKO 252 HP Palafin-Hero with Power Whip, then invests the remaining EVs in HP.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Palossand's unique typing and good defensive bulk make it a solid physically defensive wall that can check the likes of Iron Hands, Slither Wing, and non-Stakeout Great Tusk while also spinblocking against Great Tusk and Iron Treads. Stealth Rock can provide entry hazard support, whereas Skill Swap lets Palossand check Aerilate Dragonite and better handle offensive Great Tusk and Regenerator switch-ins. Palossand pairs well with specially defensive walls such as Ice Scales Corviknight and Garganacl that appreciate its ability to take physical hits. Frail offensive attackers that are susceptible to priority like Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao also appreciate Palossand's ability to soak up offensive hits. Palossand can have a tough time dealing with specially offensive Ghost-types like Dragapult and Gholdengo, so paring it with Ting-Lu or Kingambit is recommended. Ceruledge can also pose a problem to Palossand, as it can 2HKO Palossand after Swords Dance and survive any one attack, so paring it with something that can handle Ceruledge like Great Tusk or Iron Hands is advised.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Ghost)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Thanks to Disguise, Mimikyu is a premier revenge killer and sweeper in Battle Stadium Singles!

  • Tera Blast is a risky option due to making your team commit to Terastallizing Mimikyu, but it can be worth it for muscling through Mimikyu's usual checks, such as Corviknight and Tera Steel Pokemon.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: The extra damage on Shadow Sneak gives Mimikyu an easier time sweeping late-game.

  • Fire: With Tera Blast, Jolly Mimikyu has a 75% chance to OHKO Corviknight after Swords Dance, which means most other Steel-types will have a far more difficult time dealing with Mimikyu.

  • Electric: While not as effective against Steel-types as Tera Fire, it still deals massive damage to Corviknight, and gives Mimikyu better chip damage to Dondozo.

  • Normal: Tera Normal doesn't help Mimikyu offensively and makes Mimikyu vulnerable to Mach Punch and Dragon Darts, making it a niche option. However, it does severely punish Dragapult if it uses Phantom Force.

sets.name: Curse Stall
sets.description:
• The combination of Curse, Substitute, and Pain Split is devastating against key defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl and Dondozo.

  • Shadow Claw is Mimikyu's best shot at dealing damage to Gholdengo, at the cost of doing poorly against Normal-types.

  • Play Rough is Mimikyu's strongest STAB move, though it will make Mimikyu nearly helpless against Gholdengo.

  • Taunt does an even better job of shutting down defensive foes, but makes Mimikyu totally useless against Gholdengo.

Tera Types

  • Ghost or Fairy: Terastallizing this Mimikyu for extra damage output is fairly situational, but getting a bit of extra power can help late game.

  • Flying: Against common users of Fissure such as Dondozo, this gives Mimikyu a situational way to stall them out more easily while healthy.

sets.name: Trick Scarf
sets.description:
• Mimikyu might seem like an odd user of Choice Scarf with its low offenses, but with Trick and Disguise, it becomes a very disruptive Pokemon against defensive foes like Dondozo and Corviknight.

  • Shadow Sneak is a reasonable option to give Mimikyu priority after using Trick.

  • Wood Hammer hits Water-types such as Rotom-W very hard.

  • Thunder Wave or Will-O-Wisp let Mimikyu further disrupt Pokemon after using Trick, or can be used as an emergency way to stop a sweeper while still holding Choice Scarf.

  • Mimikyu should have a neutral nature with a Jolly Mint used on it. This way, Mimikyu can't be confused by eating any Berry after using Trick.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Mimikyu a good chance to OHKO Dragapult with Shadow Claw.

  • Grass: With Wood Hammer being boosted, Mimikyu OHKOes offensive Rotom-W.

  • Normal: While this makes Mimikyu far more vulnerable to Breloom, it is useful for catching other Ghost-types off guard.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Physically defensive Corviknight is a fantastic check to dangerous attackers like Garchomp, Roaring Moon, and Dragonite, an effective slow pivot, and one of the few viable entry hazard removers. The choice between Brave Bird and Body Press comes down to team need; Brave Bird nails Great Tusk and has no immunities, while Body Press is Corviknight's best option against Kingambit and Chien-Pao. Leftovers is the preferred item to provide extra longevity, but Rocky Helmet can further punish physical attackers, especially on weak hits like Scizor's and Meowscarada's U-turn. Tera Water serves as an emergency check to dangerous Fire-types like Cinderace, while Tera Ground surprises Iron Hands and Iron Moth.

Corviknight is a fantastic slow pivot, making it a great partner for frail-but-powerful teammates like Chien-Pao and Iron Valiant. It is also one of the few viable Defoggers, allowing it to partner up with teammates like Dragonite, Chien-Pao, and Volcarona that loathe Stealth Rock. Be warned, Corviknight is utterly unable to Defog against Gholdengo, so secondary entry hazard removal like Great Tusk and a reliable switch-in like Ting-Lu are recommended. Corviknight is unable to handle powerful physical Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge and Electric-types like Iron Hands. Teammates that can cover these weaknesses like Dondozo and Great Tusk are wonderful partners. Its middling special bulk makes teammates like Slowking and Ting-Lu valuable. Slowking has the added benefit of being another slow pivot as well, while Ting-Lu forms a strong entry hazard core with Corviknight and threatens Gholdengo.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Pivot Knight
sets.description:
• Corviknight's fantastic typing makes it one of the best pivots in the metagame; it easily gets dangerous teammates such as Hydreigon and Dragapult in.

  • Brave Bird's damage output generally justifies the recoil.

  • Body Press deals much more damage to Kingambit and Electric-types such as Rotom-W but makes Dragapult a problem.

  • Rocky Helmet lets Corviknight wear down physical threats more quickly while pivoting.

Tera Types

  • Corviknight's defensive typing is fantastic, so don't Terastallize too hastily and lose to more threats.

  • Dragon: Dragon and Fairy weaknesses are devastating, but in the late-game, resisting Electric and Fire can give Corviknight new win conditions against old foes such as Rotom-W.

  • Flying: Boosting Brave Bird's damage output is nice, but the secret to the Flying Tera type is that Corviknight will no longer be vulnerable to Fissure while it uses Roost.

  • Grass: Grass improves matchups against Rotom-W and Breloom significantly.

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description:
• Corviknight stands out as one of the best choices around for a defensive Steel-type, thanks to recovery and Body Press.

  • Taunt lets Corviknight effectively shut down slower defensive Pokemon, such as Dondozo.

  • Iron Head helps Corviknight check Mimikyu more easily, especially if not running Rocky Helmet.

Tera Types

  • Corviknight has a fantastic defensive typing, so only Terastallize if you need to win certain matchups, especially since it becomes vulnerable to Toxic.

  • Flying: A Flying Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing even when using Roost, making it a more reliable check to Fissure users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Fighting: With a Fighting Tera type, Body Press is easier to sweep with, as long as troublesome Fairy-types such as Mimikyu are removed.

  • Grass: Tera Grass Corviknight not only handles Rotom-W better, but can set up on Breloom.

  • Dragon: A Dragon Tera type lets Corviknight resist common attacks aimed at it, such as Electric- and Fire-type attacks. However, the new weaknesses to Fairy and Dragon make this a reactive Terastallization.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: The passive damage from Rocky Helmet against Mimikyu gives Corviknight a much easier time using Taunt over Iron Head.

  • Leftovers: Corviknight tends to stick around, so Leftovers recovery makes sense over a Berry.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• With Bulk Up giving an Attack boost, Corviknight is free from having to use Body Press for good damage output.

  • Taunt is highly recommended for shutting down Garganacl and Dondozo.

  • Iron Head is chosen for both reliable damage output and hitting Fairy-types hard.

  • Power Trip takes several boosts to get powerful, but it's Corviknight's best shot at dealing decent damage to Gholdengo, being able to break its Substitute after Bulk Up.

  • Covert Cloak makes Corviknight immune to Salt Cure's residual damage, making Corviknight a good check to Garganacl.

Tera Types

  • Remember that most of Corviknight's good Tera types leave it vulnerable to Toxic, so Terastallize carefully.

  • Dark: While it doesn't help Corviknight much defensively, a Dark Tera type lets it 2HKO 4 HP Gholdengo with Power Trip after one use of Bulk Up.

  • Flying: This Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing while using Roost, meaning Fissure users such as Dondozo are much easier to handle.

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type boosts Iron Head and removes Corviknight's Electric weakness, at the cost of making it vulnerable to Earthquake.

  • Dragon: Once Fairy- and Dragon-types are out of the way, the Dragon Tera type allows Corviknight to get around Electric- and Fire-type attacks.

  • Grass-type: A Grass Tera type is Corviknight's best way of setting up on Breloom and handling Rotom-W.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ice Scales Corviknight is a premier specially defensive pivot that can check prominent special attackers like Iron Bundle and Dragapult with its immense bulk and great typing while also providing entry hazard removal. Brave Bird is Corviknight's most consistent attack and 2HKOes or 3HKOes most special attackers, whereas Iron Head avoids recoil. Defog provides entry hazard control, which is very crucial for teams facing hazard-stacking threats like Ting-Lu and Garchomp, while U-turn provides slow pivoting support for offensive teammates. As a result, frail pokemon such as Dragapult, Iron Bundle, and Iron Moth are great teammates, as they appreciate Corviknight's ability to get them in safely. Ice Scales Corviknight struggles against strong physical attackers, so pairing it with a strong physical wall like Avalugg or Hippowdon is recommended. Even with Ice Scales, Corviknight can be susceptible to strong special attacking Fire-types like Chi-Yu and Iron Moth, so Regenerator Garchomp and Ting-Lu make good teammates. Corviknight is prone to having its Defog blocked by Good as Gold, so it's strongly recommended for it to be paired with spinners such as Great Tusk that can remove entry hazards if Corviknight is unable to.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Making use of Fur Coat to bolster its high Defense and good defensive typing, Corviknight serves as a strong physical wall that can switch into threatening attackers like non-Mold Breaker Great Tusk and Kingambit, and is a Defogger that isn't threatened by common entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Clodsire. U-turn and minimum Speed allow Corviknight to act as a slow pivot, safely bringing in offensive teammates like Volcarona and Dragonite. Corviknight's average Special Defense means that it has a hard time against special attackers, so it benefits from specially defensive teammates like Florges and Blissey. Corviknight also struggles to meaningfully damage Rock- and Steel-type foes like Garganacl and Iron Treads, so teammates like Iron Bundle and Chi-Yu that can handle these Pokemon are appreciated.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Tera Normal boosts the power of Boomburst to insane levels, being able to outright OHKO specially defensive Hippowdon and Gastrodon after only one layer of Spikes.

sets.name: Shift Gear
sets.description: Tera Normal boosts the power of Boomburst to insane levels, OHKOing Hippowdon and doing massive damage to Gastrodon and Scream Tail.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Tera Normal boosts the power of Boomburst to make up for the decreased power, being able to still have great odds to OHKO Hippowdon after 1 layer of Spikes and 2HKO Gastrodon with no entry hazards on the field.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description:
Tera Blast in conjunction with Tera Fighting gives Polteageist the necessary coverage to break past Dark-types like Tyranitar, Bisharp, and Iron Jugulis that wall it otherwise. Tera Fighting also allows Polteageist to resist Sucker Punch from Bisharp and Accelrock from Lycanroc-D as well as take neutral damage from Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak.

Tera Ghost is an alternative to maximize the power of Shadow Ball towards bulky foes like Tinkaton and Gastrodon. However, Protect should be run over Tera Blast if using Tera Ghost as Tera Blast is now a useless moveslot and Protect helps Polteageist against First Impression users like Lokix and Slither Wing.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description: Polteageist is a dangerous setup sweeper and cleaner thanks to Shell Smash, Stored Power, and its excellent Special Attack, allowing it to sweep with a single turn of setup. Giga Drain provides coverage for Ting-Lu and Ice Scales Garganacl, Strength Sap gives Polteageist a way to restore its Focus Sash after chip damage and set up on weaker physical attackers, while Substitute allows for safe setup on status-reliant walls like Blissey. Focus Sash the preferred item to safely ensure Polteageist can use Shell Smash. Polteageist can often struggle to get itself onto the field safely, so it appreciates a slow pivot from Corviknight or Shed Tail Cyclizar who can also facilitate Polteageist's setup with screens or a passed Substitute. Polteageist pairs well with physical wallbreakers like Triage Iron Hands that can break through opposing Ice Scales walls. Due to its reliance on Focus Sash, Polteageist needs reliable entry hazard removal like Cyclizar and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

vgc2023.overview:
• Hatterene is an offensive Trick Room setter that loves to take advantage of all the Dark- and Dragon-type Pokemon running around the metagame, such as Murkrow, Hydreigon, and Garchomp.

  • Hatterene needs assistance to get started. Fake Out support from Hariyama or Mold Breaker Tinkaton can stop faster Pokemon who would otherwise threaten a KO before Trick Room. Redirectors such as Amoonguss all but ensure that Trick Room gets set up. Indeedee-F in particular facilitates Hatterene very well, as it can use Trick Room, set up Psychic Terrain to protect against priority, and redirect attacks with Follow Me.

  • Additional spread damage from the likes of Torkoal, Armarouge, and Sylveon can overwhelm entire teams alongside Hatterene and close out a game. Armarouge additionally helps dissuade opposing Torkoal from utilizing Trick Room turns itself, as it can block spread moves with Wide Guard.

  • Magic Bounce renders Hatterene immune to most forms of disruption such as Taunt from Murkrow or Talonflame and Spore from Amoonguss.

  • Its low HP and middling physical bulk makes Hatterene vulnerable to most strong or super effective physical attacks. Strong priority moves, such as Dragonite's Extreme Speed and Kingambit's Sucker Punch, are problematic unless Hatterene has Psychic Terrain or Quick Guard support. Hatterene also struggles to get started against many common Ghost-types due to its low Speed and relative frailty. Gengar can threaten to either OHKO it with a STAB move or take away Hatterene's speed control with Imprison.

sets.name: Trick Room Sweeper
sets.description:
• Mystical Fire lets Hatterene deal decent damage to Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Kingambit, which it would otherwise fail to hit effectively.

  • Covert Cloak renders Hatterene immune to the secondary effects of moves like Snarl and Fake Out, which, combined with Magic Bounce, greatly limits the ways the opponent can deal with it. Life Orb makes Hatterene a far more threatening sweeper but noticeably hinders its longevity, leaving it more vulnerable to revenge killing from powerful priority moves.

  • Tera Fire lets Hatterene turn the tables on Steel-types, such as Gholdengo looking for a quick KO before it sets up Trick Room. Tera Fairy removes Hatterene's weakness to Ghost and makes Dazzling Gleam hit harder. Tera Steel gives Hatterene a slew of resistances and allows it to surprise Fairy-types like Sylveon with a super effective Tera Blast. Steel-type Tera Blast also OHKOes Garganacl, which would otherwise wall it endlessly. Tera Psychic gives Hatterene a boosted STAB option that isn't resisted by Fire-types.

  • Shadow Ball is a niche option to cover common Ghost- and Psychic-types. After You allows Hatterene to support Pokemon with higher Speed during Trick Room, such as Meowscarada and Gengar. Focus Sash is an option if Hatterene doesn't run a defensive Tera type.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more discussion and resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• With Prankster and the movepool to use it, Grimmsnarl is one of the best dual screens setters, as it is useful for setting up dangerous sweepers such as Dragonite.

  • Parting Shot is not only useful for dropping stats, but the pivoting action can let Grimmsnarl come in later to set up screens if it's in a bad matchup.

  • Thunder Wave is a reasonable alternative for crippling fast foes that may be problematic for sweeps.

  • Taunt shuts down phazers and opposing Taunts that could stop the dual screens from being set up.

  • Spirit Break hits Dragon-types, making it a good offensive move.

  • Alternatively, Foul Play is notable for breaking Gholdengo's Substitute and punishing physical setup sweepers.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Grimmsnarl should almost never Terastallize, since it's trying to support sweepers rather than deal serious damage on its own. Still, a Grass Tera type is a reasonable choice for blocking Spore from Breloom and Amoonguss.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Possessing OU's highest unboosted Speed tier makes Choice Specs Dragapult a very remarkable special wallbreaker, revenge killer, and offensive pivot. It outspeeds and threatens common offensive threats like Cinderace, Iron Moth, and even boosted foes like Choice Scarf Rotom-W and Adamant Dragonite after a Dragon Dance. Moreover, it's immune or resistant to common priority attacks like the aforementioned Dragonite's Extreme Speed, Breloom's Mach Punch, and Slither Wing's First Impression, which makes it much harder to revenge kill. A coverage move in either Flamethrower or Thunder lets Dragapult nail Corviknight, with the former also hitting other Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads, while the latter pressures Toxapex and Tera Water Garganacl. Infiltrator allows Dragapult to bypass Grimmsnarl's dual screens, Orthworm's Shed Tail, and Substitute users like Gholdengo, which gives it an edge against hyper offense teams. Tera Ghost maintains an immunity to Dragonite's Extreme Speed and strengthens Shadow Ball—its most spammable attack—notably guaranteeing the 2HKO on Corviknight and Assault Vest Iron Treads after Terastallizing. Tera Fairy prevents Dragapult from being picked off by opposing Dragapult and Sucker Punch from Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Meowscarada. Finally, Tera Dragon turns Draco Meteor into an even more powerful nuke. This takes advantage of the lack of prominent bulky Steel- and Fairy-types in the metagame, notably chunking answers to Ghost-types like Purifying Salt Garganacl and Ting-Lu and 2HKOing Unaware Clodsire.

Choice Specs Dragapult fits perfectly on bulky offense and VoltTurn teams. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Great Tusk appreciate Dragapult's U-turn bringing them in safely, and they are able to pressure its switch-ins like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, Blissey, and Garganacl. Entry hazard removers like Corviknight and Great Tusk allow Dragapult to pivot throughout the game unperturbed; the former can also pivot it in safely via U-turn, letting it threaten Gholdengo, which tends to switch into Corviknight to block its Defog. Furthermore, Corviknight and Great Tusk provide the necessary defensive backbone to switch into boosted threats such as Roaring Moon, as well as revenge kill attempts from Sucker Punch users like Kingambit and Chien-Pao. Gholdengo forms a Ghost spam core with Dragapult, as it can overwhelm a shared check in Ting-Lu, use non-Calm Mind Blissey as setup fodder, and either cripple Tera Water Garganacl with Trick or straight up dent Tera Fairy variants. Entry hazards from Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Garganacl can quickly put foes into Dragapult's KO range, especially as it tends to force a lot of switches; in return, Dragapult spinblocks foes like Great Tusk and Iron Treads in a pinch. Setup sweepers like Volcarona, Iron Valiant, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao appreciate Dragapult wallbreaking early-game for them to clean up late-game easily.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Dragapult utilizes its near-unresisted STAB moves, its blistering Speed stat, and its excellent Attack stat to function as a strong physical wallbreaker. The choice for the second move depends on what Tera type Dragapult chooses. Tera Dragon Dragapult uses Phantom Force for a Ghost-type STAB move, but Tera Ghost uses Tera Blast, since, unlike Phantom Force, it is not a two-turn move. Sucker Punch allows Dragapult to revenge kill weakened sweepers such as opposing Dragapult, as well as Iron Moth and Tera Flying Roaring Moon after some chip damage. However, be careful when using Sucker Punch, since opponents can predict it and set up. An Adamant nature gives Dragapult extra wallbreaking power, at the cost of being outsped by threats like Chien-Pao. Alternatively, a Jolly nature allows Dragapult to outspeed the entirety of the unboosted metagame. With Tera Dragon, Dragapult's Dragon Darts becomes harder to switch into; it 2HKOes walls Dragapult normally struggles with such as Ting-Lu. Tera Dragon Dragapult is also less susceptible to Sucker Punch, albeit at the cost of losing its immunity to Dragonite's Extreme Speed.

Iron Valiant is a fantastic partner, since it's able to check Dark-types such as Kingambit and Ting-Lu. Hazard removal from Pokemon like Great Tusk, Cinderace, and Corviknight make for good partners, since Dragapult's lack of longevity makes it difficult to switch in when hazards are up. Great Tusk and Corviknight are able to beat both Scizor and opposing Great Tusk, while Cinderace can threaten bulky Steel-types such as Corviknight. Dragapult benefits from entry hazards from the likes of Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl, since it can more effectively wallbreak with entry hazards up. Other pivots such as Scizor and Rotom-W appreciate that Dragapult's U-turn can bring them in. In return, Scizor can revenge kill Ice-types such as Chien-Pao, while Rotom-W can check both Corviknight and defensive Great Tusk. Paralysis support from Rotom-W can shutdown offensive Pokemon like opposing Dragapult and Roaring Moon. Lastly, Gholdengo makes for a good teammate, since it can spinblock and deny Defog and can help Dragapult overwhelm shared checks like Kingambit and Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Unlike its more offensively oriented Choice item sets, this Dragapult set goes for a more multifunctional approach. Dragapult's unmatched Speed tier, in conjunction with STAB Dragon Darts, allows it to snipe key offensive threats such as Roaring Moon, Iron Moth, and Cinderace with some prior chip damage. This often means that Dragapult will force a lot of switches which can be capitalized on with Will-O-Wisp to spread status and power up Hex. Will-O-Wisp also allows Dragapult to avoid Sucker Punch, which can come in handy against Cinderace, Kingambit, and Meowscarada. With a burn and Stealth Rock up, Hex 2HKOs Defensive Corviknight, Amoonguss, and Dondozo, allowing Dragapult to pick apart balanced cores. Finally, U-Turn rounds out the set, letting Dragapult keep momentum up even against hard counters like Ting-Lu and Garganacl. 252 Speed EVs with a Hasty nature ensure that Dragapult outspeeds the entire unboosted tier. 76 Attack EVs ensure an OHKO on Roaring Moon with Dragon Darts, while the rest of the EVs are put into Special Attack. Although Dragapult does not typically find itself needing to Terastallize very often, Ghost is most commonly used to power up Hex even further. For example, Tera Ghost Hex does a minimum of 84% to a burnt Defensive Great Tusk. In a pinch however, Terastallization can be used defensively to avoid OHKOs like from Chien-Pao's Ice Shard.

Because of the amount of utility it provides, Dragapult appreciates plentiful chip damage from its teammates, as it lacks immediate power. All forms of entry hazards are greatly appreciated due to Dragapult's ability to force out the opponent, so entry hazard setters like Garganacl, Great Tusk, Glimmora and Ting-Lu form good teammates. Stealth Rock is particularly important since it secures important 2HKOs with Hex. Among the entry hazard setters, Garganacl has fantastic synergy with Dragapult, as it is able to set up Stealth Rock while also chipping down foes with Salt Cure. Partners that can spread status such as Rotom-W and Skeledirge are also excellent teammates. Since Ting-Lu and Garganacl stonewall this set, teammates that scare them out such as Offensive Great Tusk and Banded Meowscarada are great partners. Tera Flying Covert Cloak Gholdengo forms a particularly potent Ghost spam core with Dragapult, as it can turn common counters to Dragapult such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Garganacl into setup fodder. Physical sweepers like Chien-Pao and Kingambit appreciate having their counters like Corviknight and Great Tusk crippled with burns and have solid type synergy with Dragapult. Due to this set being most potent in the mid- to late-game, it's more at home in teams with solid defensive backbones that can sponge hits. Defensive pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Hatterene, Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Amoonguss can all soak damage for Dragapult from common checks like Garganacl, Ting-Lu, and Kingambit while setting up entry hazards, spreading status, or dealing chip damage, allowing Dragapult to clean up later in the game.

Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Physical Attacker
sets.description:
• Dragapult's incredible Speed makes it a very effective hit-and-run attacker.

  • Phantom Force is risky due to the two turns making Dragapult vulnerable to Normal-types and surprise Terastallization, but lack of many strong Ghost-resistant foes makes it an effective late-game cleaning move.

Tera Types

  • Dragon and Ghost: Terastallizing into either of Dragapult's STAB types makes it even more difficult to wall, with Ghost being notable for letting Dragapult use a less risky STAB move in Tera Blast.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives a valuable Fairy-type resistance and is a more powerful tool against Steel-types at the cost of a Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting vastly improves Dragapult's match-up against Kingambit and Choice Scarf Meowscarada.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band guarantees that Breloom is OHKOed through its Focus Sash with Dragon Darts.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb makes Sucker Punch a less risky option.

  • Choice Scarf: This may seem like overkill, but Choice Scarf gives Dragapult the edge over other Choice Scarf foes, such as Hydreigon and Gholdengo.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• Despite Dragapult's insane Speed stat, Dragon Dance insulates it from popular Choice Scarf revenge killers such as Gholdengo, making it a great sweeper.

  • Phantom Force's drawback can be an issue when Normal-types are potentially around, but its great coverage still makes it good way to clean teams.

Tera Types

  • Dragon: Not only does this make Dragon Darts difficult to wall, but it clinches a OHKO on Breloom regardless of the item.

  • Steel: Steel covers a lot of Dragapult's former weaknesses, letting it set up on new foes such as Mimikyu.

  • Fire: Not only does this make Fairy-types easier to deal with, but it can help Dragapult sweep through defensive Steel-types such as Corviknight with Tera Blast.

  • Ghost: Terastallizing into a Ghost-type gives Dragapult the option for a much more reliable STAB move in Tera Blast, at the cost of not helping it set up against new threats.

  • Fighting: With Tera Fighting, Kingambit is far less likely to stop Dragapult's sweep.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
• Draco Meteor and Shadow Ball give Dragapult high-powered and reliable STAB attacks, respectively.

  • Thunderbolt is the recommended coverage move for hitting Corviknight and Dondozo hard.

  • Even though it's weak, U-turn is a reasonable consideration for pivoting and breaking Mimikyu's Disguise.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: The stronger Shadow Ball makes this Dragapult difficult to wall outside of Normal-types and Ghost resistant foes such as Garganacl.

  • Fire: The Fairy-type resistance and powerful Flamethrower can make the Stealth Rock weakness worth it.

  • Fighting: The resistance to Sucker Punch Tera Fighting provides can be key in stopping Kingambit.

  • Electric: Tera Electric Dragapult still deals plenty of damage to Corviknight, while being less vulnerable to Dondozo's Water-type attacks compared to a Fire Tera type.

sets.name: Bulky Status
sets.description:
• With usable bulk bolstered by Will-O-Wisp, this Dragapult can severely punish its weaker offensive checks.

  • Disable makes Dragapult rely on Will-O-Wisp for Normal-types, but when combined with Substitute, it defeats Choice-locked foes and those that rely on one specific move to beat Dragapult.

  • Draco Meteor improves Dragapult against other Dragon-types, particularly Hydreigon and itself.

  • Flamethrower lets Dragapult deal decent unconditional damage to Steel-types, with Kingambit being the biggest target.

  • Surf is decent coverage, but its main niche is with Tera Water to hit foes that may Terastallize into a Fire-type to block Will-O-Wisp, such as Garchomp, Annihilape, and Azumarill.

  • Dragon Darts with a Naive nature gives Dragapult a consequence-free Dragon-type attack and decent mixed attacking potential.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Steel Tera type is great for general defense and Fairy-types such as Azumarill and Mimikyu.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Dragapult preforms better against most Dragon-types.

  • Water: Besides being a good defensive typing, a Water Tera type lets Dragapult hit common Tera Fire foes such as Garchomp much harder.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• Dragapult's high Speed combined with Reflect and Light Screen make it an effective dual screens lead.

  • Curse reduces Dragapult's HP to get it off the field quickly once it has set up screens. It also forces opponents to use recovery moves or switch out, allowing Dragapult's teammates to get in and set up safely. Curse is Dragapult’s best option to bypass Substitute, Protect, and Mimikyu.

  • Shadow Ball breaks Focus Sash, hits Ghosts like Gholdengo and opposing Dragapult that normally threaten it, and breaks Mimikyu's Disguise. Notably Gholdengo stops Curse with Good as Gold, making Dragapult totally helpless against it if it does not carry Shadow Ball.

  • Alternatively, Dragon Darts can be used for more power to make Dragapult more self-sufficient when it has to stay on the field, and breaks Focus Sash as well. Its dual-hit nature makes it bypass most Substitutes.

  • Will-O-Wisp can be used to cripple physical attackers. In tandem with Reflect, this can be a potent strategy to allow the next Pokemon to set up nearly risk-free.

Tera Types

  • Ghost / Dragon: Dragapult, as a screens supporter, should not normally Terastallize, but if you are in a bad spot, Ghost and Dragon power up its STAB move of choice.

  • Steel: A defensive typing like Steel can allow Dragapult to survive certain moves like boosted Cloyster's Icicle Spear and boosted Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush and retaliate.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type is useful for enemy Infiltrator Dragapult's Dragon Darts. However, Dragapult should rarely Tera, as dual screens are best used to support a different Tera Pokemon.

Items

  • Focus Sash: While Light Clay is standard, Focus Sash nearly guarantees setting at least one screen without having to Terastallize, in the event Dragapult leads off against Choice Scarf users like Gholdengo, Hydreigon, and Meowscarada.

sets.name: Sheer Force + Life Orb
sets.description: Sheer Force + Life Orb Dragapult, in addition to being the fastest unboosted threat in the metagame, is one of the few credible mixed attackers, making it great for picking apart Fur Coat + Ice Scales defensive cores. Dragon Rush nails common specially defensive walls like Blissey and Ice Scales Clodsire and Garganacl while Thunderbolt beats bulky Waters like Toxapex. Fire Blast hits Steel-types like Corviknight and Iron Treads, while Will-O-Wisp punishes switch-ins Dragapult cannot reliably overwhelm like Ting-Lu. Dragapult pairs extremely well with pivots like Corviknight, Slither Wing, and Slowking, as they can get it on the field in advantageous positions where it can fire off Shadow Ball. Dragapult does struggle against bulky foes it cannot hit super effectively like Florges, so a secondary, more dedicated wallbreaker like Kingambit or Great Tusk is recommended.

sets.name: Hadron Engine
sets.description: Choice Specs Hadron Engine Dragapult is a premier wallbreaker and pivot that takes advantage of Electric Terrain to overwhelm common Ice Scales users. Shadow Ball and Draco Meteor provide it with consistent and powerful STAB attacks, respectively. Thunderbolt is a strong coverage move that is also boosted by Electric Terrain, denting RegenVest Kingambit and giving Dragapult a chance to 2HKO Ice Scales Corviknight and Toxapex after Stealth Rock. Strong physical attackers like Great Tusk and Iron Valiant pair well with Dragapult, which brings them in with U-turn on Pokemon they can threaten out, such as Blissey and Iron Treads. In return, Dragapult breaks through Fur Coat users like Hippodown and Corviknight for them. Dragapult is forced out by priority users such as Aerilate Dragonite, so Pokemon that can switch into them like Gholdengo and Clodsire are recommended. Dragapult pairs well with defensive pivots like Corviknight and Iron Hands that can safely bring it onto the field to outspeed and threaten a majority of offensive threats, such and Chein-Pao. Entry hazards setters like Ting-Lu and Palossand can set Spikes and Stealth Rock, respectively, which helps Dragapult break past switch-ins like Kingambit more easily.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: CRITTY CAT
sets.description:
• With its good Attack, Speed, and access to Flower Trick and Knock Off, Meowscarada is a potent cleaner that is also hard to switch into.

  • With its guaranteed critical hit, Flower Trick is a dangerous cleaning move once resistances to it have been sufficiently chipped.

  • Trick can help Choice-locked sets incapacitate an annoying wall, such as Dondozo or Amoonguss, by locking them into a single move. Make sure to use a neutral nature and use a Jolly Mint on Meowscarada, so it won't get confused by eating any Berry after Trick.

  • Low Kick OHKOs Hydreigon and Kingambit if using Protean.

Abilities

  • Protean: Protean’s type-shifting allows Meowscarada to make the most of its colorful movepool, particularly on Choice-locked sets, where the limitation to only changing types once is effectively nullified.

  • Overgrow: If you intend to make use of a Tera type other than Grass or switch moves often, Overgrow is worth considering, as it allows Meowscarada more flexibility with its moves by not changing type and removing STAB from Flower Trick or Knock Off.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band boosted Meowscarada hits incredibly hard, and with its naturally high Speed it can serve as a cleaner and a potential wallbreaker.

  • Choice Scarf: With the Speed offered via Choice Scarf, Meowscarada can threaten otherwise faster foes, such as Dragapult, potentially putting more pressure on offensive teams.

Tera Types

  • Grass: While Terastallizing does override Protean, Tera Grass Meowscarada can be used to power through teams ill-prepared for it. Dual screens teams in particular are especially vulnerable to the sheer power of Choice Band-boosted Tera Grass Flower Trick.

sets.name: Focus Sash
sets.description:
• With its good Speed and wide movepool, Meowscarada makes for a potent lead.

  • Flower Trick offers gives Meowscarada good and consistent damage output.

  • Sucker Punch allows Meowscarada to better handle foes such as Dragapult and Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

  • Toxic Spikes’s forced passive damage is a great asset for the fast-paced teams Meowscarada generally finds itself on.

  • Thanks to its good Speed, Meowscarada makes particularly excellent use of Taunt, shutting down other entry hazard leads such as Garchomp and Hippowdon.

  • Play Rough provides good coverage for Fighting- and Dragon-types that might otherwise pose issues.

  • Low Kick is worth considering if your team struggles with Kingambit, though it can be hard to fit.

Abilities

  • Overgrow: Since this Meowscarada set aims to be more of a supportive Pokemon, Overgrow is preferred to keep STAB on its attacks after it uses its support moves.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Defensive Gator
sets.description:
• Thanks to instant recovery and Unaware, Skeledirge distinguishes itself as one of the premier physical walls.

  • Torch Song is a powerful STAB move that allows Skeledirge to become a potential win condition.

  • Will-O-Wisp vastly improves Skeledirge's match-up against fearsome physical foes such as Kingambit.

  • Yawn works exceptionally well with Stealth Rock support.

  • Substitute is a good way around status, especially Garganacl's Salt Cure. It also becomes effective when used on Toxic Spikes teams.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Terastallizing into the Fairy typing removes Skeledirges glaring weakness to Dark and provides an overall superior defensive typing. It also provides a neutral typing for the inevitable Shadow Balls that will be thrown at Skeledirge. With proper timing, Skeledirge can defeat counters meant to deal with it, most notably Gholdengo and Dragapult.

  • Water: A Water Tera type lets Skeledirge take on formerly super effective attacks such as Liquidation, providing a valuable turn to burn the offender. It should be noted that Tera Water tends to be a safer option versus the ubiquitous Gholdengo, as it does not often run Thunderbolt.

Items

  • Leftovers: The residual recovery helps Skeledirge use Torch Song more freely.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: This makes Skeledirge less pressured to Terastallize to rid itself of its Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak ignores the secondary effects of Salt Cure and Acid Spray, improving Skeledirge's match-up against Garganacl and Bellibolt.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 244 Def / 12 Spe with Bold: The EVs are set to maximize physical bulk with just enough Speed to outpace uninvested Corviknight.

  • 220 HP / 164 Def / 4 SpA / 108 SpD / 12 Spe with Calm: This EV spread allows both Tera Fairy and Water Skeledirge to avoid a 2HKO from a plethora of offensive threats, such as Modest Gholdengo, Adamant Azumarill, and Choice Specs Dragapult, while still boasting significant physical bulk. With this spread, alternative move slot choices such as Encore and Substitute become viable and allow Skeledirge to wreak havoc on slower defensive and balance teams.

sets.name: Good as Gold
sets.description: Good as Gold Skeledirge's great bulk, typing, and movepool make it a decent deterrent to entry hazard removal and excellent status spreader. Will-O-Wisp + Hex spreads chip damage, neuters physical attackers, and gives Skeledirge the most firepower; Roar + Shadow Ball is a more consistent alternative that deters setup and racks up entry hazard chip. Teammates that can reliably set entry hazards long-term such as Fur Coat or Regenerator Garchomp and Regenerator Ting-Lu are great partners, as they greatly appreciate Skeledirge's ability to deter hazard-removing attempts. Pokemon that check the likes of Dragapult and Iron Bundle such as Ice Scales Corviknight and specially defensive Desolate Land Volcarona make for great defensive partners alongside Skeledirge. Strong wallbreakers such as Great Tusk, Iron Bundle, and Iron Valiant appreciate Skeledirge’s ability to keep entry hazards up by preventing Corviknight's Defog—and potentially risk a spinblock against Great Tusk and Iron Treads—allowing them to further pressure the opposing team. 12 Speed EVs let Skeledirge outspeed and either damage or burn Corviknight.

sets.name: Bulky
sets.description:
• While Quaquaval's bulk is only serviceable, having both Roost and a great support movepool makes it a reasonable defensive option.

  • Taunt pairs particularly well with Bulk Up, letting it set up on surprising foes such as Corviknight.

  • Substitute lets Quaquaval stall out OHKO moves from the likes of Dondozo, and it protects it from Garganacl's Salt Cure.

  • Encore not only gives Quaquaval new chances to set up, but also punishes passive play from Unaware walls such as Skeledirge.

Tera Types

  • Flying: While it has very little defensive synergy with Quaquaval's previous typing, Tera Flying lets Quaquaval effectively stall out Dondozo if using Taunt, or Substitute and Encore together.

  • Grass: Tera Grass makes Quaquaval's match-up against Rotom-W much smoother.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Quaquaval can set up against most defensive Garchomp thanks to the Dragon Tail immunity.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet pairs well with Taunt and Tera Flying, letting Quaquaval easily play around Dondozo and Corviknight while setting up Bulk Up.

  • Covert Cloak: If running Substitute isn't possible, Covert Cloak is Quaquaval's best shot at defeating Garganacl.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 156 SpD / 100 Spe with Jolly: This EV spread allows Quaquaval to outspeed Meowscarada while raising its special bulk. If not using Bulk Up, running Defense EVs is also viable instead.

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 76 Def / 116 SpD / 68 Spe with Careful: The Special Defense investment and Careful nature let Quaquaval survive Choice Specs Hydreigon's Draco Meteor at full health, and the Speed lets it outspeed Garchomp after Aqua Step. The Defense investment lets Quaquaval avoid a 2HKO from Tera Dark Black Glasses Kingambit with one Supreme Overlord boost.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximizing Speed ensures that Quaquaval outspeeds Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Dragapult after using Aqua Step.

sets.name: Moxie Sweeper
sets.description:
• Aqua Step and Moxie give Quaquaval a niche as a late-game sweeper that doesn't always need a turn of setup.

  • Ice Spinner is Quaquaval's best way of dealing big damage to Dragonite and Salamence.

  • Encore lets Quaquaval punish slower foes such as Corviknight by getting an easy setup opportunity.

  • Roost might seem odd on such an offensive Pokemon, but it helps Quaquaval avoid getting worn down against bulkier teams.

  • Alternatively, Aqua Jet's ability to pick off weakened threats pairs very well with Moxie, giving it new potential win conditions.

Tera Types

  • Water: Boosting Aqua Step's power opens up new sweeping chances late-game.

  • Grass: Tera Grass lets Quaquaval potentially set up against would-be checks such as Rotom-W.

  • Electric: Tera Electric lets Quaquaval deal massive damage to Azumarill and wear down Dondozo switch-ins with Tera Blast.

  • Fire: With Tera Fire, Quaquaval can get around Will-O-Wisp.

Items

  • Life Orb: The power increase makes sweeping with Aqua Step easier, especially against bulkier foes.

  • Focus Sash: With Focus Sash, Quaquaval trades potential wallbreaking for getting surprise sweeps against more offensive teams.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• With Choice Band, Quaquaval goes all-in on attempting to sweep with Aqua Step.

  • Aqua Jet is an alternative way to sweep late-game.

Tera Types

  • Water: Since this set is so focused on Aqua Step, Tera Water is a must-have.

sets.name: Making Waves (3 Attacks + Roost)
sets.description: Quaquaval provides a decent offensive presence and valuable utility. Its typing in Water / Fighting and Roost allow it to soft check and threaten out foes like Chi-Yu, Roaring Moon, and Iron Moth. It's a solid spinner because it threatens out common entry hazard setters like Great Tusk, Garganacl, and Ting-Lu and spinblockers like Skeledirge and non-Fur Coat Gholdengo. Aqua Step or Rapid Spin's Speed boost allows it to outspeed would-be revenge killers such as Iron Bundle and Iron Valiant, which lets Quaquaval potentially clean up late-game. Mystic Water + Primordial Sea provides more offensive presence and works well with Aqua Step for a recoil-less Water-type attack, while Magic Guard lets Quaquaval ignore Life Orb and Wave Crash recoil and lets it comfortably switch into entry hazards to make use of Rapid Spin. Rapid Spin variants pair well with hazard-stacking teammates like Garchomp and Ting-Lu; they also help switch into Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Ceruledge that wall Quaquaval, the latter of which can spinblock it reliably.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Quaquaval is a solid wallbreaker thanks to its high-Base Power STAB moves backed up by a good Attack stat. Primordial Sea amplifies Wave Crash's power to even higher levels, but Sword of Ruin is an option to boost its other attacks, notably 2HKOing defensive Desolate Land Volcarona with Close Combat. Ice Spinner gives it coverage for Dragon-types such as Dragonite and Dragapult. U-turn lets Quaquaval gain momentum, taking advantage of Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Ceruledge and Volcarona. Because of this, Quaquaval pairs well with teammates that can threaten them like Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Dragonite; the former two also provide entry hazards to punish foes trying to switch around Quaquaval, while the latter appreciates Quaquaval wallbreaking early-game for it to sweep easier. A Jolly nature can be used to outspeed Slither Wing and neutral-natured Baxcalibur and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Pawmot's good offensive stats and unique support movepool give it a good niche in the metagame.

  • Double Shock and Close Combat are its most important attacks, but note that it can only use Double Shock once without Terastallizing. Once Terastillized, Pawmot you can use Double Shock continuously for big damage, even on foes that resist it.

  • Mach Punch allows Pawmot to revenge kill better, hitting Meowscarada, Choice Scarf Hydreigon, and Tera Steel Dragapult super effectively.

  • Ice Punch gives Pawmot coverage against Ground-types, most notably Clodsire and Garchomp, in addition to hitting Dragapult for lots of damage.

  • Revival Blessing's one shot of reviving a teammate give Pawmot an extremely unique niche in turning battles around, though it doesn't fit all offensive teams.

  • Nuzzle paralyzes foes, and it's notably one of the few ways to inflict paralysis on Gholdengo. This move is best when used with a Focus Sash, as Pawmot can paralyze the foe and outspeed it the next turn, getting another move off before it faints.

  • Encore does a great job of punishing passive play, and prevents easy setup from slower defensive foes such as Garganacl.

  • Fake Out can be used to get an edge against common Focus Sash leads such as Meowscarada.

Abilities

  • Iron Fist: This boosts the power of Mach Punch and Ice Punch, giving Pawmot more powerful priority and coverage.

  • Volt Absorb: Volt Absorb's Electric immunity stops Magnezone, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H from using Volt Switch to create safe switch-ins.

  • Natural Cure: This allows Pawmot to take status moves more freely, such as Yawn from Dondozo or Will-o-Wisp from Skeledirge.

Items

  • Life Orb: Life Orbs enables easier revenge kills at the cost of recoil.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash trades the damage boost from the other items for better opportunities to use support moves.

  • Magnet: Magnet will power up Double Shock without the recoil from Life Orb, and it also frees up Life Orb for a teammate to use instead.

Tera Types

  • Electric: An Electric Tera Type allows Pawmot to continuously use Double Shock, making it an effective late-game cleaner.
