sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description:
• Kingambit sets itself apart from most other Dark-types with its bulk and typing, which make it a reasonable check against Gholdengo that lack Focus Blast.

  • Guillotine makes Kingambit far more difficult to wall with foes such as Dondozo.

  • Low Kick is Kingambit's best option against other Kingambit.

  • Brick Break is rather weak, but it does help against Reflect and Light Screen, in addition to helping against opposing Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Dark: A Dark Tera type makes Kingambit even harder to wall and removes its irritating Ground weakness.

  • Flying: This Tera type covers Kingambit's issues with Fighting- and Ground-type attacks very well.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Kingambit gains a resistance to Fighting and can still deal with Dragon-types, but it becomes vulnerable to Gholdengo.

Abilities

  • Supreme Overload: This is generally the more consistent ability since Intimidate foes are not very common.

  • Defiant: Defiant is still useful for punishing speed control options such as Rock Tomb, especially alongside Sucker Punch.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe: This simple spread maximizes bulk and power.

  • 108 HP / 252 Atk / 148 Spe: This EV spread has enough Speed to outspeed most Corviknight and Skeledirge, and it still has enough bulk to survive one unboosted Body Press from Corviknight. Since this is a fairly congested Speed range, feel free to move some Attack EVs to Speed.

Items

  • Black Glasses: While its boost to Dark-type attacks isn't as high as Life Orb's, Black Glasses is a better fit for Kingambit's bulk due to the lack of recoil.

  • Sitrus Berry: The burst of recovery helps Kingambit check Gholdengo better.

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest makes Kingambit a better check against Gholdengo and Hydreigon.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Kingambit is a dangerous wallbreaker, owing to great base stats and Adaptability. After using Swords Dance, Kingambit threatens the entire tier, including incredibly bulky physical walls such as Fur Coat Corviknight and Hippowdon. Sucker Punch picks off faster threats, such as Iron Bundle and Dragapult, making it difficult to check offensively. Life Orb provides the highest damage boost to Kingambit's attacks, notably ensuring a 2HKO on Fur Coat Corviknight; alternatively, Black Glasses provides a damage boost without digging into Kingambit's limited healthpool, while Leftovers allows Kingambit to reliably switch in on weaker attacks. Kingambit best fits on offense teams, which appreciate its massive damage output and can provide opportunities for it to switch in safely. Slow pivoting teammates, such as RegenVest Iron Treads and Ice Scales Corviknight, are recommended, as they can safely pivot Kingambit in and also clear entry hazards. 144 Speed EVs are used to outspeed uninvested Corviknight. Kingambit is incredibly threatened by Great Tusk and Iron Hands, as both can easily live even boosted hits and threaten to OHKO back, so teammates like Florges and Iron Valiant are appreciated.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Great Tusk has a solid niche as a defensive Pokemon by virtue of its utility, movepool, bulk, and typing. It can adequately check Pokemon like Kingambit, Cinderace, and Iron Hands, threatening them with a strong Earthquake in return. Stealth Rock lets Great Tusk compress even more roles, chipping away at the opposition. If another Stealth Rock user is already on the team, however, Body Press can take advantage of its high Defense stat and better threaten the likes of Ting-Lu and Roaring Moon. Body Press also lets Great Tusk catch Rotom-W with greater chip damage than Knock Off does on the switch. Knock Off provides valuable item removal, getting rid of Leftovers from Pokemon like Dondozo, Corviknight, and Hatterene, as well as Heavy-Duty Boots from Volcarona and Dragonite. Additionally, Knock Off is Great Tusk's only initial way to hit Air Balloon Gholdengo, which can't OHKO this defensive set. Rapid Spin, besides clearing entry hazards, also allows Great Tusk to outspeed faster foes like Focus Sash Glimmora and Gholdengo. Tera Fighting gets rid of Great Tusk's Ground typing, giving it a better matchup against Pokemon like Chien-Pao while also strengthening Body Press if it is used. Alternatively, Tera Steel can give Great Tusk valuable resistances to Fairy, Grass, and Ice, turning the tables on Hatterene and Chien-Pao. Leftovers greatly increases Great Tusk's longevity; however, Rocky Helmet can be used to wear down Pokemon like Scizor and Cinderace over time.

After Great Tusk sets Stealth Rock, Corviknight effortlessly switches in and uses Defog to remove entry hazards, so Pokemon like Cinderace, Gholdengo, and Rotom-W that handle it are great partners. With no good way to hit Flying-types and Pokemon that use Tera Flying, Great Tusk can be set up on very quickly, most notably against the likes of Dragonite and Roaring Moon;even though the former dislikes Knock Off. Therefore, checks to these such as Dondozo and Corviknight are appreciated. A different Stealth Rock setter like Garganacl or Ting-Lu lets Great Tusk comfortably run Body Press without losing out on anything major. Ting-Lu also forms a potent entry hazard-stacking core with Great Tusk via Spikes. Further, it takes on the special attackers that Great Tusk struggles with, like Gholdengo, Choice Specs Dragapult, and Volcarona. Great Tusk is forced out by wallbreakers like Iron Valiant and Quaquaval, so teammates that can check them like Amoonguss and Toxapex are welcome. Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth appreciate the entry hazard removal that Great Tusk provides. Great Tusk's defensive qualities greatly help frail wallbreakers like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Chien-Pao, as these Pokemon need strong defensive Pokemon to fall back on very often.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• Tera Ground can turn Headlong Rush into a devastating STAB attack that can break through bulky targets Great Tusk normally wouldn’t, such as Scream Tail and Dondozo.
  • Tera Fighting lets Great Tusk crush Corviknight with Close Combat, which severely hurts defensive structures reliant on it. This opens up powerful teammates like Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.
  • Earthquake makes Great Tusk harder to revenge kill than Headlong Rush does, as it doesn’t drop its defenses.
  • Rapid Spin works well for teams weak to entry hazards. It's a great way to support powerful threats weak to Stealth Rock, like Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Iron Bundle.
  • Knock Off provides fantastic item-removing support, and it especially cripples walls reliant on Leftovers like Scream Tail and Dondozo, allowing its team to more easily break past them.
  • Play Rough can be used to OHKO Koraidon without Terastallizing, as well as beating opposing Great Tusk. However, it has very little practical use outside of this.
  • Choice Scarf Great Tusk functions most effectively as a wallbreaker in the early- and mid-game, suited best for offensive structures that struggle with physical walls like the aforementioned Scream Tail and Dondozo. When building teams, remember Great Tusk must use Terastallization to actually break through said walls, so it may be hard for teammates to Terastallize.
  • Choice Band Great Tusk only functions well on Sticky Web teams, where the stronger and slower set appreciates Sticky Web dropping foes' Speed.
  • Koraidon is a great partner, setting up sun and activating Protosynthesis for Great Tusk. It further resists Water- and Grass-type moves aimed at Great Tusk, weakening the former. Koraidon also effectively baits in Skeledirge, which Great Tusk reliably threatens.
  • Miraidon is also a great partner, as it can threaten Flying-types, like Corviknight and the rarer Pelipper and Dragonite. This helps to make Great Tusk’s Headlong Rush much more spammable.
  • Gholdengo is also a good partner for Great Tusk, as it resists Ice-, Fairy-, and Grass-type moves aimed at Great Tusk, and it can threaten to KO Ice- and Fairy-types with super effective STAB Make It Rain. In addition, Gholdengo also blocks all hazard removal, helping to wear down walls for Great Tusk's team to eventually break through.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description:
• Great Tusk is the best offensive Stealth Rock or Rapid Spin user in the tier thanks to its solid typing and good physical bulk.
  • If Great Tusk is paired with Pokemon such as Corviknight, then Stealth Rock can be run instead of Rapid Spin. If paired with teammates that set Stealth Rock, then the best set would be Rapid Spin / Headlong Rush / Close Combat / Knock Off. Knock Off makes progress on Corviknight and covers the Air Balloon Gholdengo matchup.
  • Tera Ground lets Great Tusk deal incredible damage with Headlong Rush while also letting it survive Flutter Mane's Moonblast from full HP. Tera Steel flips the Fairy matchup and lets Great Tusk take on Ice- and Dragon-type attacks, but the additional weaknesses to Fighting and Ground make Great Tusk unable to take on Koraidon, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads easily.
  • Great Tusk can be used to take on entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Iron Treads one-on-one by forcing them out and removing hazards. Jolly is usually preferred to outspeed Gholdengo, Modest Chi-Yu, and Glimmora, but Adamant lets Tera Ground Headlong Rush OHKO Koraidon and specially defensive Annihilape after one layer of Spikes or Stealth Rock.
  • Great Tusk should be used aggressively to force out and keep entry hazards off the field against other setters, such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads, since Great Tusk is generally difficult to switch into. Great Tusk pairs well with Koraidon thanks to Orichalcum Pulse's sun, letting Great Tusk become an incredibly potent wallbreaker, and Great Tusk can clear entry hazards so that Koraidon can repeatedly come in. Miraidon also appreciates Great Tusk, as it forces out common checks such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads. Great Tusk also appreciates Blissey being able to take on all of the special attackers that force Great Tusk out, such as Flutter Mane, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description:
• Bulk Up allows Great Tusk to be a threatening sweeper. It can comfortably set up on common physical walls like Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, Corviknight, and defensive Great Tusk.
  • The STAB combination of Headlong Rush and Close Combat hits most physical walls for at least neutral damage. Earthquake may be used as the Ground-type STAB move to avoid defensive drops, but it is a weaker move, and it can't secure important OHKOs and 2HKOs at +1 Attack against some physical walls such as Toxapex, Scream Tail, and Alomomola.
  • A Jolly nature is used to outspeed all viable unboosted Pokemon after one Rapid Spin. An Adamant nature makes Great Tusk stronger while still letting it outspeed unboosted Iron Bundle at +1 Speed, but it misses out on outspeeding maximum Speed Gholdengo and tying Jolly Great Tusk.
  • Terastallizing into the Ground typing boosts Headlong Rush and guarantees some additional OHKOs and 2HKOs on foes like Toxapex and Scream Tail. Additionally, getting rid of the Fighting typing lets Great Tusk survive Fairy-type attacks such as Dazzling Gleam from Miraidon and Moonblast from Flutter Mane without Life Orb or Choice Specs, and it facilitates taking Dazzling Gleam and Play Rough from Scream Tail and Alomomola.
  • Alternatively, using Tera Steel gives Great Tusk resistances to Fairy-type attacks, Ice-type attacks from Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle, and Draco Meteor from Miraidon, allowing it to surprise them with a strong attack.
  • Koraidon is a solid partner because its sun activates Great Tusk's Protosynthesis, making its attacks even stronger. In return, Great Tusk can break through or strongly dent common Koraidon checks like Scream Tail, Alomomola, and Skeledirge, which allows Koraidon to clean more easily. Miraidon is also an excellent teammate, since Great Tusk can easily hard switch into its common checks and either threaten them with its attacks or set up on them.
  • Special attackers like Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle hugely threaten Great Tusk, so it is recommended to pair it with appropriate special walls like Blissey, Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire. Gothitelle is a less popular pick but it helps eliminate bulky checks like Dondozo and Pelliper, allowing Great Tusk to sweep more easily.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Fighting)
sets.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Defensive Spinner
sets.description: Rapid Spin, Knock Off, and great physical bulk make Great Tusk a fantastic utility spinner. It can check dangerous physical attackers such as Ceruledge, Slither Wing, Kingambit, and Roaring Moon and retaliate with its beefy Earthquake and Body Press. It matches up well against common entry hazard setters like Garganacl and Clodsire, and it threatens spinblockers with Knock Off; Knock Off also augments its teammates' entry hazards by removing Heavy-Duty Boots. Leftovers gives it much needed recovery—especially alongside Regenerator—but Heavy-Duty Boots prevents it from being overwhelmed by the entry hazards it must remove. Teammates such as Blissey and Slowking can cover opposing special attackers that target Great Tusk's lower Special Defense. In return, they appreciate Great Tusk dealing with physical attackers like opposing Great Tusk.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Choice Band Great Tusk is a dangerous wallbreaker thanks to its high-powered STAB moves and either Mold Breaker to bypass Fur Coat or Stakeout for the reliable power against non-Fur Coat targets. Knock Off has no immunities, unlike both STAB options, and removes key items like Leftovers from Corviknight. Ice Spinner breaks through defensive Dragonite and Garchomp with a clean OHKO. Fast specially offensive pivots like Iron Bundle, Dragapult, and Noivern can bring Great Tusk in safely to pressure their specially defensive switch-ins like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Blissey. Defensive pivots such as Corviknight and RegenVest Iron Hands are also good options, as they can switch into faster threats like Iron Bundle and Iron Moth, respectively, which force Great Tusk out. Dragonite and Ceruledge appreciate Great Tusk wallbreaking early-game by threatening Fur Coat users like Corviknight and Garganacl, which lets them clean up late-game more easily.

sets.name: Booster Energy (Speed)
sets.description:
• Bulk Up further boosts Great Tusk's naturally high Attack and Defense stats.
  • Booster Energy lets Great Tusk outspeed Meowscarada, Annihilape, and Corviknight.
  • Knock Off can be used to remove Choice items from Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Magnezone.
  • Great Tusk’s EV spread allows for maximum Attack while still procuring the Speed boost from its Booster Energy. The HP investment increases Great Tusk's bulk and ensures its HP remains odd to have a better matchup against Leech Seed.
  • Due to Great Tusk's low Special Defense stat, it's weak to bulky special attackers such as Weakness Policy or Air Balloon Gholdengo and Skeledirge.
  • Great Tusk is strong against Pokemon that it is able to outspeed due to Booster Energy and should use a damaging move against Choice Specs Iron Bundle, Meowscarada, and Chien Pao.

sets.name: Wish Support
sets.description: Scream Tail should very rarely be Terastillized, as its typing is needed to check foes like Gallade, Hawlucha, and Noivern and there are far better users of the mechanic.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description: Scream Tail should very rarely be Terastillized, as its typing is needed to check foes like Gallade, Hawlucha, and Noivern and there are far better users of the mechanic. Additionally, its sole purpose is to set up dual screens and entry hazards, and changing to another type will not make a massive impact compared to another teammate.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Pixilate
sets.description: Pixilate Boomburst Scream Tail functions as a bulky utility option and a potentially powerful setup threat. With Boomburst, Scream Tail can topple many threats such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon, making it far less passive than most walls. Calm Mind lets it serve as a bulky wincon, while Flamethrower deters Steel-types like Gholdengo from switching in and Stealth Rock lets it make progress against foes it cannot threaten like Ice Scales Clodsire. Scream Tail's great matchup into common Dark-, Fighting-, and Dragon-types makes it a great partner for offensive teammates that struggle with those foes, like Iron Bundle, Garchomp, and Iron Treads. Scream Tail struggles with Poison- and Fire-types such as Clodsire and Volcarona, as well as Steel-types if it does not run Flamethrower, so teammates such as Iron Bundle and Iron Treads are appreciated.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Defensive Scream Tail serves as an answer to Fighting- and Dragon-types such as Iron Hands and Dragonite. Encore locks Pokemon into moves that they do not want to be locked into, such as Volcarona with Quiver Dance or Morning Sun, Blissey into Soft-Boiled, and Avalugg into Recover. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be ran if the team needs entry hazard support. Fur Coat is the most common ability, but Regenerator allows it to better check opposing pivots like Iron Hands; alternatively, Prankster Encore can be used to deter opposing setup attempts. Scream Tail serves as a defensive answer to Fighting- and Dragon-types, so Pokemon such as Blissey and Kingambit are appreciated. It is unable to check several common physical attackers like Ceruledge and Kingambit, so secondary physically defensive teammates like Regenerator Iron Hands are appreciated.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Flutter Mane functions as a great wallbreaker and revenge killer thanks to its already high Special Attack and Choice Specs, allowing it to break through unprepared teams with its dual unresisted STAB moves.
  • Mystical Fire 2HKOes specially defensive Iron Treads and serves as a way to hit Corviknight.
  • Psyshock is preferred in the last slot as a way to threaten specially defensive walls such as Blissey and Clodsire. Thunderbolt can be used to 2HKO Mirror Armor Corviknight and Toxapex.
  • Flutter Mane can Terastallize into the Fairy typing to further increase its damage output.
  • Flutter Mane pairs extremely well with Koraidon, as it can set up sun to further boost Flutter Mane's already impressive Speed. Koraidon can also pivot out via U-turn against Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Skeledirge, which Flutter Mane can threaten.
  • Physically defensive Corviknight is a great partner for Flutter Mane that can come in on attacks that target Flutter Mane's weaker physical defenses while also providing it safe entry via a slow U-turn.
  • This set appreciates entry hazard support from Great Tusk, which can also threaten Flutter Mane's checks such as Clodsire, Blissey, and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Flutter Mane can deal incredible damage to every Pokemon in the metagame due to its great coverage, notably 2HKOing most defensive foes.
  • Calm Mind allows Flutter Mane to OHKO Ting-Lu with Tera Fairy-boosted Moonblast, as well as defensive Great Tusk with Shadow Ball. Taunt can be used instead to stop bulky Pokemon like Blissey, Clodsire, Corviknight, and Toxapex from recovering health, giving Flutter Mane the advantage against bulkier teams.
  • Thunderbolt covers specially defensive Corviknight and Toxapex, whereas Mystical Fire hits Iron Treads.
  • Psyshock is a great option to strongly hit Blissey and Clodsire; Clodsire is an important target, as it otherwise walls Calm Mind + Life Orb variants due to Unaware.
  • Booster Energy can be used instead of Life Orb to boost Speed upon entry, but the drop off in damage is noticeable.
  • Tera Fairy allows Flutter Mane to dish out great levels of damage and lets it resist Sucker Punch from Chien-Pao. Tera Ghost allows Flutter Mane to 2HKO Corviknight and Toxapex. Tera Fire lets Flutter Mane resist Ice Shard from Chien-Pao and Ice Beam and Freeze-Dry from Iron Bundle, while Tera Normal makes it immune to Shadow Ball from opposing Flutter Mane.
  • Entry hazard removal from the likes of Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads is appreciated, as residual damage can stack up quickly between entry hazards and Life Orb recoil.
  • Koraidon acts as a great teammate, setting sun for Flutter Mane's Protosynthesis to trigger.

sets.name: Calm Mind (Ghost)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Normalize
sets.description: Normalize Flutter-Mane is a dangerous setup sweeper that requires specific counterplay to deal with. Entrainment + Normalize prevents foes from damaging Flutter Mane, with its Fairy typing giving it an immunity to the common Draco Plate Judgment. Quiver Dance increases damage output and allows Flutter Mane to outspeed and nullify would-be faster threats like Zacian-C. Taunt prevents defensive checks from PP stalling Flutter Mane and denies Glare; alternatively, Strength Sap provides Flutter Mane with longevity, allowing it to repeatedly switch into passive Pokemon. Pixie Plate lets Flutter Mane hit Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Arceus-Dark super effectively, whereas Spooky Plate lets it hit Imposter users and opposing Ghost-types harder. A Modest nature provides a power boost, while Timid can be used to outspeed positive natured Arceus formes to use Entrainment first. Flutter Mane struggles against bulky Magic Bounce and Good as Gold users, so strong wallbreakers such as Choice Band Zacian-C and Choice Specs Miraidon are good partners. Even with Normalize, Flutter Mane can still be statused by moves like Glare and Will-O-Wisp, so a Heal Bell user can be helpful. Flutter Mane also has poor physical bulk, so slow defensive pivots like Ting-Lu and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra are appreciated to bring Flutter Mane in safely while also providing Knock Off support to remove Ability Shield.

sets.name: All-Out-Attacker
sets.description:
Protective Pads are an option that let Slither Wing more freely attack Talonflame, although Choice Band sets can still potentially OHKO it with Wild Charge while risking one Flame Body burn.

Tera Bug powers up Slither Wing's First Impression and U-turn to maximize its revenge killing potential and chip damage. Tera Ghost is an option to spinblock and check Lucario, Maushold, and opposing Slither Wing. Tera Fighting powers up Close Combat to maximize damage versus Quagsire and Hippowdon.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Tera Bug powers up Slither Wing's First Impression and U-turn damage, making it harder to pivot around and letting it revenge kill faster Pokemon such as full HP Floatzel.

sets.name: Bulky Pivot
sets.description:
Morning Sun lets Slither Wing use its typing more effectively to check Pokemon such as opposing Slither Wing and Tsareena. Stun Spore instead lets Slither Wing cripple switch-ins like Salamence and Talonflame to create openings for teammates such as Choice Specs Toxtricity.

Tera Ghost lets Slither Wing spinblock and check Maushold and Lucario. Tera Bug is an alternative that improves its ability to revenge kill Pokemon.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Slither Wing’s massive Attack stat combined with STAB U-turn and First Impression allow it to be a great wallbreaker, revenge killer, and offensive pivot. Earthquake is an option to bash Skeledirge whereas Flare Blitz is better into Corviknight and bulky Fighting resistant foes such as Scream Tail and Fur Coat Florges on non-Tinted Lens sets. Tinted Lens is useful for revenge killing Dragapult, Dragonite, and Volcarona with First Impression after minimal chip, Sword of Ruin provides the most power against neutral targets, and Oricalchum Pulse is recommended for Flare Blitz variants. Special wallbreaker partners such as Iron Bundle and Iron Moth break Fur Coat Pokemon that trouble Slither Wing and appreciate Slither Wings ability to break the Ice Scales walls they hate in return. Slither Wing loves being partnered with bulky pivots such as Chilly Reception Slowking, Corviknight, and Desolate Land Volcarona to get it in safely against the opposing team and start punching holes in defensive cores. Slither Wing tends to invite in Fire-types onto the field, so fire resistant teammates such as Garchomp and Garganacl are appreciated.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description: Good natural bulk, useful defensive typing, and an excellent support movepool make Slither Wing a good mixed defense pivot that repeatedly pivots and most notably switches into Ground-types like Great Tusk. Regenerator makes the most of its pivoting ability, but Fur Coat and Unaware are options for greater bulk or deterring setup, respectively. Will-O-Wisp allows it to punish switch-ins like Iron Valiant and Iron Hands with a burn. Its massive Attack allows it to use STAB U-turn to maintain momentum while bringing in more offensive teammates like Chi-Yu and Iron Bundle. Even with investment, Slither Wing struggles to check certain physical attackers like Ceruledge and Dragonite, so Pokemon like Fur Coat Garganacl and Corviknight make good teammates. Slither Wing also has difficulty against Fairy- and Flying-types like Scream Tail and Noivern, so it appreciates teammates like Iron Moth and Garganacl that are able to handle them.

sets.name: Hazards Lead
sets.description: Tera Ghost is used to potentially spinblock while utilizing Sandy Shocks's solid matchup versus Defog users, such as Talonflame, to help keep its entry hazards up.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Tera Ice lets Sandy Shocks break through Kilowattrel and Hippowdon with Tera Blast, which otherwise wall it. Tera Grass instead lets it OHKO Gastrodon with Tera Blast.

Tera Ground should be used when running entry hazards to put as much pressure on Quagsire and Gastrodon as possible, but Sandy Shocks is not a high-value Terastillization user in this case.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Tera Ice lets Sandy Shocks break through Kilowattrel and Hippowdon with Tera Blast, which otherwise wall it. Tera Grass instead lets it OHKO Gastrodon with Tera Blast.

Sandy Shocks can alternatively run Power Gem to break Kilowattrel while running Tera Ground to let it 2HKO Gastrodon without giving up its Ground typing.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Tera Ground lets Sandy Shocks apply as much pressure as it can against Quagsire and weakened Gastrodon with Earth Power, making it harder for them to take advantage of its Choice lock.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Ground)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Hadron Engine
sets.description: Hadron Engine Sandy Shocks is a powerful attacker with good STAB coverage and utility in Spikes. Choice Scarf outspeeds major threats like Iron Bundle, Dragapult, Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and +2 Modest Polteageist, while Choice Specs better pressures opposing walls like Ice Scales Corviknight and Iron Treads. Spikes forces progress even when the opponent has a solid answer to Sandy Shocks, such as Ting-Lu. Sandy Shocks pairs well with strong attackers like Dragapult and Iron Valiant, as they take advantage of weakened special walls and can fire off Terrain-boosted Thunderbolts. Sandy Shocks also appreciates Pokemon that can switch into Ground-type attacks, such as Corviknight, which also gives a slow U-turn to bring Sandy Shocks in safely, and Garchomp, which can also help with stacking entry hazards. Entry hazard removal is particularly helpful, as the Pokemon that usually switch into Sandy Shocks, like Ting-Lu, will often use the opportunity to set entry hazards.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
• A decent defensive typing allows Iron Treads to act as a check to Miraidon and Flutter Mane, and use the opportunity to remove or set entry hazards.
  • Knock Off cripples common switch-ins such as Ting-Lu and Corviknight, while Volt Switch keeps momentum for your team.
  • 16 IVs in Defense mean that Iron Treads will receive a Special Defense boost in Electric Terrain, helping with switching into Miraidon.
  • Iron Treads can use Tera Fairy to remove its weaknesses to Fighting and Fire, which can be helpful versus Koraidon and Chien-Pao, and with taking coverage from Miraidon and Flutter Mane. However, it loses its immunity to Electric and resistances to Dragon and Fairy. Iron Treads can alternatively use Tera Ground for an extra boost to Earthquake, but it suffers from similar demerits as Tera Fairy.
  • Since both Miraidon and Flutter Mane have Fire-type coverage options, Iron Treads appreciates being paired with Pokemon such as Ting-Lu that can handle those attacks. Choice Scarf Koraidon and Booster Energy Flutter Mane are also good teammates, as they can revenge kill Miraidon and Flutter Mane while benefitting from Iron Treads removing entry hazards.
  • Skeledirge's ability to check Koraidon and Iron Valiant also makes it a great partner for Iron Treads. Teammates that can switch into Great Tusk such as Dondozo and Alomomola also pair well, with Alomomola even providing Wish support to increase Iron Treads's longevity.

sets.name: Fast Stealth Rock
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Regenerator Pivot
sets.description: RegenVest Iron Treads is a great specially defensive pivot and spinner. It is able to switch into prominent special attackers such as Gholdengo and threaten them out. Knock Off removes key items like Heavy-Duty Boots and deters spinblockers from switching in, and Volt Switch has excellent synergy with Regenerator. If its teammates already provide adequate entry hazard control, Iron Head and Ice Spinner are options to target Scream Tail and Dragonite, respectively. A Sassy nature with minimum Speed investment ensures the slowest possible pivot with Volt Switch. Iron Treads appreciates physically defensive teammates like Fur Coat Slowking, which can form a VoltTurn core to bring in powerful-but-frail teammates like Iron Bundle and Dragapult.

sets.name: Heavy-Duty Boots
sets.description:
• Freeze-Dry and Hydro Pump make Iron Bundle incredibly threatening with perfect coverage.
  • Taunt can be used to stop recovery and status attempts from walls like Corviknight, while Flip Turn can gain momentum. Encore is effective at PP stalling recovery attempts from Pokemon while also locking Pokemon into suboptimal moves like Stealth Rock to take advantage of.
  • Tera Ice boosts Freeze-Dry's and Ice Beam's power to high levels and also removes the neutrality to Freeze-Dry from opposing Iron Bundle, making a potential mirror match safer.
  • Tera Water Iron Bundle has immense power on Hydro Pump; Tera Water also removes its Fighting-type weakness and Fire-type neutrality, which helps against Choice Scarf Great Tusk and Koraidon trying to revenge kill it.
  • Iron Bundle has to use its high Speed to force out frail Pokemon or force defensive Terastallization, both of which it can take advantage of.
  • Getting Iron Bundle safe switch-ins on defensive Pokemon that are threatened by Hydro Pump is the best way to use its offensive capabilities, allowing for defensive answers to be Taunted or pivoted on to wear down opposing teams.
  • Pelipper and Miraidon are strong teammates for Iron Bundle, providing rain and Electric Terrain support to power it up.
  • Entry hazard setters are also very strong, since Iron Bundle appreciates checks like Corviknight and Annihilape being worn down. It also can use Taunt to stop Defog Corviknight and pressure the premier spinners in Great Tusk and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• The combination of Hydro Pump and Freeze-Dry gives Iron Bundle an unresisted STAB combination, making it extremely threatening with Choice Specs.
  • Flip Turn allows Iron Bundle to pivot in order to gain momentum, while Ice Beam OHKOes Koraidon and uninvested Miraidon.
  • Tera Ice allows Iron Bundle to further boost its Ice-type moves and resist Freeze-Dry from opposing Iron Bundle and Ditto. Tera Water is a good option on teams with rain support in order to let it 2HKO Heavy-Duty Boots Blissey in rain after slight chip.
  • Choice Specs allows Iron Bundle to 2HKO walls such as Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Scream Tail with Hydro Pump as well as Toxapex with Freeze-Dry.
  • Miraidon is a great teammate, as it can lure in Pokemon weak to Hydro Pump such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads and pivot into Iron Bundle using U-turn. It also sets Electric Terrain, giving Iron Bundle a Speed boost upon entry.
  • Entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight, Iron Treads, and defensive Great Tusk are great teammates, as Iron Bundle can get worn down pretty quickly from repeatedly switching into Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description: • The given EV spread, nature and Assault Vest allow Iron Bundle to survive a ruin-boosted Overheat from Chi-Yu and OHKO it in return with Hydro Pump while retaining enough speed to move before Meowscarada. Incidentally, the spread also allows Iron Bundle to survive a ruin-boosted Extreme Speed from a Choice Band Tera Normal Dragonite.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Iron Bundle is a terrifying wallbreaker with incredible Speed and unresisted STAB coverage. Primordial Sea counters Desolate Land and allows Hydro Pump to OHKO most non-Ice Scales foes, while Mold Breaker breaks through walls like Ice Scales Corviknight. For the last slot, U-turn is used to pivot against Water-immune foes like Desolate Land Volcarona, while Flip Turn hits Pokemon like Ice Scales Blissey and Corviknight harder. Defensive pivots such as Corviknight help Iron Bundle safely switch into and pressure threats like Chi-Yu and Iron Moth. Strong physical attackers like Baxcalibur and Great Tusk are also good teammates, as Iron Bundle often forces in specially defensive walls that these Pokemon can threaten; Rapid Spin Great Tusk can also double as entry hazard removal. Pokemon who can set entry hazards like Ting-Lu and Garchomp are great partners for Iron Bundle, as they help it wear down its checks faster.

sets.name: Magic Guard Disrupter
sets.description: In addition to its strong wallbreaking capabilities, Iron Bundle's immense Speed allows it to outspeed almost the entire unboosted metagame and utilize Encore or Taunt to serve as a disrupter, hindering setup sweepers like Nasty Plot Gholdengo and passive Pokemon like Clodsire. Encore punishes setup sweepers and can burn extra recovery PP from opposing walls, while Taunt denies recovery in the first place. U-turn allows Iron Bundle to escape from dangerous switch-ins like Desolate Land Iron Moth while maintaining momentum, and Magic Guard keeps it from getting worn down by entry hazards through repeated switches. Iron Bundle struggles against specially defensive Pokemon like Florges and Blissey, so it pairs well with physically offensive teammates like Kingambit and Ceruledge. Iron Bundle also has low Special Defense, so it appreciates teammates like Ice Scales Corviknight and Clodsire that can take special attacks well.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Assault Vest (Fighting)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: A huge HP stat and STAB Volt Switch make RegenVest Iron Hands a valuable specially defensive pivot that can switch into threats like Dragapult, Iron Bundle, and Chi-Yu. Aside from dissuading Flying-types like Dragonite and Noivern from switching into it, Ice Punch significantly harms Ground-types like Garchomp and Clodsire, allowing Iron Hands to pivot more freely with Volt Switch. Special wallbreakers like Iron Bundle and Noivern form a VoltTurn core with Iron Hands, and they appreciate being brought in on physical walls like Avalugg and Scream Tail via its Volt Switch. Corviknight can remove entry hazards, which would prevent Iron Hands from freely pivoting, with Defog and check threats like Iron Valiant and Great Tusk for it. Minimum Speed investment allows Iron Hands to pull off slow pivots for frail offensive teammates.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fur Coat Iron Hands uses its titanic bulk to check prominent attackers like Ceruledge and Kingambit while its solid Attack and Swords Dance prevent it from being passive. Drain Punch provides much-needed recovery as well as threatens Pokemon like Blissey and Cyclizar. Thunder Punch hits Fighting-resistant foes like Iron Moth and Iron Valiant, while Ice Punch covers Pokemon like Dragonite and Garchomp. Earthquake provides coverage for Pokemon like Clodsire that Iron Hands would otherwise struggle against. Iron Hands can also use Volt Switch alongside its low Speed to serve as a bulky slow pivot to safely bring in frail offensive teammates like Iron Valiant and Iron Bundle. Because of its below average Special Defense, Iron Hands pairs well with specially defensive teammates like Blissey and Ice Scales Corviknight. Iron Hands also struggles against Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Scream Tail, so it appreciates teammates like Gholdengo and Iron Moth that can take them on.

sets.name: Triage
sets.description: Iron Hands is the premier Belly Drum + Triage user thanks to its excellent bulk, Attack and STAB Drain Punch. With a free turn of setup, it can sweep frailer teams or clean up weakened balance teams. Ice Punch is a good coverage move to deal with threats such as Great Tusk and Hippowdon that otherwise can check it, while Earthquake is another coverage option that can better deal with Fur Coat Gholdengo. The 132 Speed EVs outpace Skeledirge, which would otherwise check Iron Hands with Will-O-Wisp. Frailer offensive teammates such as Iron Moth and Dragapult appreciate Iron Hands's ability to break through their common checks such as Garganacl and Ice Scales Corviknight. Iron Hands appreciates being brought in safely by slow pivots like Corviknight or by Shed Tail Cyclizar. Iron Hands can also have a tough time dealing with Fur Coat and Unaware walls like Hippowdon, so pairing it with a strong special attacker like Iron Bundle to deal with them is recommended.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Iron Moth is a powerful special attacker that also provides good defensive utility thanks to Desolate Land and Morning Sun. Its near-unique offensive typing lets it threaten common walls like Ice Scales Corviknight and Scream Tail, especially when boosted by sun. U-turn can be used to maintain momentum against predicted switch-ins like Garchomp and Garganacl, while Toxic Spikes punishes switch-ins with status. Iron Moth complements Ice Scales Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers their vulnerability to Iron Bundle. Pokemon like Dragapult and Dragonite appreciate Iron Moth taking advantage of their Steel-type checks like Corviknight.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Specially defensive Iron Moth uses its solid bulk, good defensive typing, and sun-boosted Morning Sun to consistently check foes like Iron Bundle, Volcarona, and some Iron Valiant variants. It's not entirely passive either, as the boosts from Fiery Dance under sun allow it to eventually overwhelm passive foes like Blissey, Scream Tail, and Florges. U-turn lets it gain momentum by pivoting out safely, and Toxic Spikes punishes grounded foes like Garganacl, Ting-Lu, and Iron Hands. Due to its devastating Ground weakness, Ground-immune Pokemon like Corviknight and Dragonite make good pairings with it. Iron Moth works well with wallbreakers like Great Tusk and Iron Bundle, as they appreciate being given free entry to threaten its switch-ins like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl. Iron Moth is a great complement to common special walls like Ice Scales Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers several of their weaknesses like Iron Bundle and Volcarona.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• With good bulk, an immunity to burn, and just enough Speed to work, Baxcalibur is a powerful Dragon Dance sweeper.

  • Icicle Spear KOes Breloom and Mimikyu through Focus Sash and Disguise respectively.

  • While Glaive Rush is valuable for late-game sweeping, it does make Baxcalibur very vulnerable to bulky OHKO move users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Alternatively, Ice Shard means Baxcalibur will have a difficult time breaking past bulky Steel-types early-game, but it makes it an effective cleaner otherwise.

Tera Types

  • Dragon: This makes Glaive Rush deal obscene damage and removes weaknesses to Mach Punch and Bullet Punch.

  • Electric: When paired with Tera Blast, this is Life Orb Baxcalibur's best shot at dealing damage to Dondozo switch-ins. The paralysis immunity also helps Baxcalibur set up against Chansey with less risk.

  • Steel: With a Tera type of Steel, Baxcalibur can set up on Mimikyu and Dragon-type attacks.

Items

  • Life Orb: This helps Baxcalibur sweep reliably and ensures Icicle Spear OHKOes Breloom through Focus Sash.

  • Loaded Dice: With a guaranteed 4 hits from Icicle Spear, Baxcalibur is able to always OHKO offensive Mimikyu after Dragon Dance.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash may seem like a waste with Baxcalibur's bulk, but it provides new set up opportunities and eases match-ups against other Dragon-types.

sets.name: All-Out Attacker
sets.description:
• Baxcalibur's bulk and the wonderful Ice Shard means it doesn't need to set-up to become a powerful threat.

  • Icicle Spear is recommended despite its inconsistent damage, as it deals damage through Mimikyu's disguise and potentially KOes Focus Sash users like Breloom and Meowscarada.

  • Glaive Rush makes Baxcalibur very vulnerable to getting KOed the next turn, but it is still the least risky Dragon-type STAB move. Remember that Ice Shard will remove Glaive Rush's negative effects as well.

Tera Types

  • Ground: A Ground Tera type gives Baxcalibur a reliable STAB move in Earthquake, resistance to Stealth Rock, and removes a ton of weaknesses, all at the cost of losing to Water-types such as Rotom-W.

  • Electric: With Tera Electric, Baxcalibur's Tera Blast deals massive damage to Corviknight that lack a set up move, Azumarill, does good chip damage to Dondozo, and gains a valuable resistance to Gholdengo's Make It Rain.

  • Ice: Boosting the power of Ice Shard gives Choice Band Baxcalibur new revenge kill chances, and makes wall breaking with Icicle Spear easier.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Baxcalibur's bulk makes it an excellent user of Assault Vest, making it particularly effective against Rotom formes.

  • Choice Band: With Choice Band, Baxcalibur becomes an immediate threat, threatening to 2HKO physical walls such as Dondozo.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe with Adamant: This simple EV spread maximizes Baxcalibur's bulk and power.

  • 116 HP / 252 Atk / 140 Spe with Jolly: The Speed investment here outspeeds Modest Gholdengo and Adamant Dragonite.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: If using Choice Band, winning Speed ties against opposing Baxcalibur makes maximum Speed much more appealing.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description: Baxcalibur is a powerful setup sweeper thanks to its great stats and fantastic STAB coverage. Dragon Dance patches up its below-average Speed to facilitate a late-game sweep, while Swords Dance is better suited for wallbreaking and cleaning up with Ice Shard; Jolly is recommended on Dragon Dance sets to outpace Dragapult at +1. Earthquake is the preferred move on Dragon Dance sets to hit Iron Hands and Garganacl. Heavy-Duty Boots preserves Baxcalibur's bulk to make setup easier. Mold Breaker beats Fur Coat Pokemon such as Garganacl, while Sword of Ruin provides the most damage against other targets. Baxcalibur fits best on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its ability to both wallbreak and sweep. It pairs well with other strong wallbreakers such as Orichalcum Pulse Ceruledge, as they can overwhelm their shared checks. Special attackers such as Iron Bundle and Chi-Yu are good partners, as they threaten out the physically defensive Pokemon that can give Baxcalibur trouble.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Choice Band Baxcalibur is a threatening attacker that overwhelms common walls such as Hippowdon, Dragapult, and Great Tusk with its powerful STAB moves, especially with Ice's vaunted offensive coverage. Ice Shard threatens many offensive Pokemon like Dragapult, Sandy Shocks, and Great Tusk. Earthquake threatens the Steel- and Fire-types that resist Baxcalibur’s STAB moves such as Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Choice Band Baxcalibur fits best on bulky offense teams that appreciate its ability to force damage on walls for its teammates. Its weakness to Stealth Rock makes entry hazard removers like U-turn Corviknight, Iron Treads, and Great Tusk great teammates. Other physical attackers such as Ceruledge are good partners, as they can overload common physically defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge. Special attackers such as Iron Valiant and Iron Bundle also make good partners, as they can threaten the physically defensive Pokemon that Baxcalibur has trouble breaking.

sets.name: Air Balloon
sets.description:
Thanks to its great typing and Good as Gold, Gholdengo is a setup sweeper that's notably difficult to deal with. Having an additional Ground immunity with Air Balloon further improves Gholdengo's already great typing, letting it switch in on Pokemon that otherwise threaten it, such as Garchomp and Iron Treads. This is especially useful against the latter, as Air Balloon strengthens Gholdengo's ability to block entry hazard removal. Maximum Speed investment is for outspeeding Dragonite and uninvested Great Tusk. 252 Special Attack EVs and Nasty Plot makes Gholdengo's STAB moves very threatening against neutral foes. Fighting and Dark Tera types give Gholdengo the option to Terastallize defensively; notably, Tera Fighting lessens the impact of moves like Crunch from Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon. Tera Dark is useful in a pinch to resist attacks such as Shadow Ball from Dragapult and opposing Gholdengo.

Entry hazard setters like Great Tusk and Glimmora are the most profitable teammates for Gholdengo, as its ability and typing ensure that their entry hazards stay around as long as Gholdengo does. Hyper offense staples such as Chien-Pao and Iron Valiant benefit greatly from the constant presence of entry hazards to break down bulkier cores; in return, Gholdengo gets teammates that synergize with its role as a wallbreaker, applying heavy pressure throughout a game to Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Rotom-W. Offensive Pokemon that outspeed and OHKO Gholdengo, such as Cinderace, Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Knock Off variants of Great Tusk, threaten to completely shut down Gholdengo; defensive teammates like Garganacl, Dondozo and Skeledirge can help mitigate some of these weaknesses.
